routes.description: Easy climbs from Temple Basin. Follow the Cassidy ski tow to gain the area south of Bill’s Basin.

routes.name: Via Cons Track
routes.description: Reached via Cons Track, which ascends on the Southwest Ridge from the Bealey River crossing on the Punchbowl Falls track. Once the bushline is reached continue ascending the ridge on loose rock. At the base of the bluffs, a rough trail sidles northwards ascending slowly under the bluffs. After 250 metres a steep scree gully is reached. Ascend this to the easier boulder slopes of the main ridge.

routes.name: Aicken–Blimit Traverse
routes.description: Ascend Mt Aicken. From the summit, the long tortuous ridge that encloses the Punchbowl Falls Creek catchment is visible. Continue along this ridge. Most obstacles tend to be gendarmes, being generally bypassed on one or other side (mostly Punchbowl Creek side). Most can be climbed directly, but this increases the grade. Towards Blimit the ridge rock rises in 30°–60° slabs, some with extreme exposure. Protection is sparse, but the climbing is easy (Grades 12–14). This buttress can be avoided by sidling out under its southern flank and ascending a narrow, loose gully to join the South Ridge. Descend to Bill’s Basin.

routes.name: TEMPLE BASIN AREA, Ski Touring.
routes.description:
Map K33
Temple Basin skifield is accessed via a steep foot track from the summit of the Arthur’s Pass highway. The main ski basin is under the face of Mount Temple, with a rope tow running up to Temple Col. A few keen skiers have attempted to ski off the summit of Mount Temple, but this is extreme terrain and you really need to know what you’re doing before going there.
On the other (eastern) side of Temple Col, a few people also ski into the upper Mingha.
The Bill’s Basin snow field is under the peak of Blimit. It is accessed by ascending on the true right of the rope tow above the accommodation lodges, and sidling north to Page Shelter. Once in the downhill basin, zig-zag onto the ridge that flanks its southern side, and cross this ridge to enter Bill’s Basin. It is possible to continue along the ridge to the SW to Mt Cassidy (1850m). Beware of cornice on this ridge and the summit of Cassidy.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aoraki/the-.name: Blizzard Pk
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aoraki/the-.description: Good skiing above the Horace Walker Glacier.

routes.name: North East Ridge
routes.description:
From the Stag–Reid Creek forks follow the true left of Reid Creek through spaniards and long
tussock to pick up the spur at J34 383830 / BW18 283 214. Follow this to the range crest. Tussock
gives way to a narrow and decaying rock arête, although there are some more stable sidling
options on tussock. At 1460 metres, scramble up a short section of steep loose rock.
routes.ascent: Phil Willis, Austen A Deans, 13 March 1948

routes.name: Northern Route
routes.description:
Follow the open gully opposite Drain Off Creek up from the Waitaha River, and cut out onto
the ridge on the true right of this open gully at about 1500–1600 metres. Join the North East
Ridge higher up.

routes.name: From County Hut
routes.description:
Follow Bloomfield Creek to the forks at J34 357809 / BW18 257 193. Climb the spur between the
forks to about Pt 1892 metres.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/otago/elcho.name: Boanerges
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/otago/elcho.description: Boanerges was named by Grave, Ombler, Watson and Pinder, who completed the first ascent of the mountain. The Ford car in which they traveled was called Boanerges, which in the Old Testament was ‘a son of thunder’.

routes.name: West Ridge
routes.description:
From near the Huxley Forks Hut gain height through the forest and subalpine 
vegetation and follow the steep slopes to the summit. Descent for the first 
party was via the south east ridge.
routes.ascent: N.Baker, T.Beckett, Wilson December 1934

routes.name: 44 South
routes.description:
This late summer route ascends the steep bluffs immediately beneath the Blair 
Glacier. Climb right of centre up the bluffs, cross the short moraine to 
reach the glacier and crampon to the summit. Best tackled when the danger of 
avalanches has disappeared, and the bluffs are dry.
routes.ascent: Ross Cullen April 1994

routes.name: South East Ridge
routes.description:
From the Huxley bridge gain height through the beech forest, then follow the 
narrow ridge up the tussock slopes to the peak.
routes.ascent: Selwyn Grave, Stan Ombler, Brian Pinder, Len Watson December 1934

routes.name: The Eclipse Traverse
routes.description:
This alpine traverse begins at the high point to the north of Boanerges and ends at Pt. 2072. This deserves to be a classic skyline traverse of the area. It is easily accssible, the climbing is interesting, the rock is good, the views are superb, and there is exposure and interesting scrambling to boot. An evolution of this could be to link into a GT of Taiaha.

Ascend steep bush to Pt 1642. The first ascensionists went direct on the SE Ridge, the rock here is quite good, and provides a nice warm up. Other parties have traversed out to the north and then climbed steep snow to the snow arete at 1900m. Ascend the final point to the ridge, either by going straight up (beware cornices) or sidle around to the south where you can ascend a steep gully for 30m. 

From here travel north along the skyline taking in all the high points. Multiple bivy spots are found along the way. The overall quality of the rock on this ridgeline is quite good, especially over the first third of the traverse. The rock deteriorates as you near Pt. 2072.  3 rappels were required off the various high points - these will depend on conditions and your confidence. Descent was into Paradise Creek via steep snow slopes east of Pt. 2072,. There is a hunters/game trail that sidles/parallels Paradise Gorge. This spits you into the Hopkins Valley just upstream of the Huxley river mouth. The first ascensionists soloed the whole route over two days and found ice up to WI3/rock climbing up to Grade 12.
routes.ascent: A. Sanders, O. Dowling - November 2022

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/fiordland/d.name: Bobs Buttress
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/fiordland/d.description: The prominent pointy peak to the east of Adelaide.

routes.name: North face
routes.description: 6 pitches. Takes a line up the slabs.
routes.ascent: Jo Kippax, Sean Waters, Dec 1992.

routes.name: Something Simply Starry
routes.description: 3 pitch route on the prominent arête just west of Bobs Buttress peak.
routes.ascent: Jo Kippax, Sean Waters, Dec 1992.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/main-divide.name: Bonds Pk
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/main-divide.description: Southern Alps Ka Tiritiri O Te Moana

routes.name: From South Mathias River
routes.description:
Follow the South Mathias River, climbing scree and snow slopes immediately south of Bonds
Peak. The bluffs are passed without difficulty – above the bluffs take a long snow slope to the
summit rocks then up some tricky slabs to the top.
routes.ascent: Edith Wallace, Gerry Auton, Nowell Syme, A (Bun) Wicks, December 1950

routes.name: South Couloir
routes.description:
From the north side of the South Mathias River, climb gentle slopes to the base of an obvious
couloir and follow this almost directly to the summit.
routes.ascent: John Entwisle, John Gaze, 1980

routes.name: From Bond Creek
routes.description:
A small glacier gives easy access from the north. A straightforward scramble follows on rock
and scree.
routes.ascent: Austin A Deans, Phil H Willis, R F Fryer, 27 August 1937

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aspiring/hu.name: Mt Bonpland
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aspiring/hu.description: The first recorded ascent was by W.J.P Hodgkins and E. Bryant in 1894.

routes.name: East Face.
routes.description: From Kinloch, ascend to the bush line before crossing the northeast slope of Bold Peak to gain the notch in the ridge between Bold Peak and Bonpland. Easy snow slopes on the east side lead to a short scramble of good rock before final snow slopes.

routes.name: The West Ridge.
routes.description: From Kay Creek climb high on the west ridge then sidle around on to the north face and scramble to the summit..

routes.name: East Face-North Ridge.
routes.description: Follow the Glacier Burn track until snow fields under East Face are reached. Climb the prominent couloir leading to the north ridge of Bonpland.

routes.name: The East Face Direct
routes.description: Climb the smaller couloir gaining access to the south ridge or go directly up East Face from Bryant Glacier/ snowfield.

routes.name: East Faces
routes.description: From the Waihopai valley, walk up Gosling Stream to Gosling Hut (6 bunks, standard, no mattresses). The stream forks about 1.2km upstream from the hut. The true right branch soon becomes rugged; bushcrash past a waterfall on true right, following a cairned trail, into upper basins and on to the summit. The true left branch is easily followed through open forest and across large tussock and scree basins to the summit ridge.

routes.name: East Ridge
routes.description: From the Waihopai valley, walk up Gosling Stream to Gosling Hut (6 bunks, standard, no mattresses). From Gosling Hut, continue upstream for about 1.2 km and take the true left fork. Once on the ridge, a deep cleft and gendarme at about 1880m requires a rope, but this could be avoided by climbing a steep gully from the north-east basin.

routes.name: West Ridge
routes.description: From the Leatham Valley head up Boulder Stream. At about 3.3km from the mouth of Boulder Stream, on its north bank, is an obvious side stream, which leads to a low saddle into upper Station Creek (best to avoid the lower creek). Good campsite here. Gain the long rocky ridge, crossing three minor bumps, leading to the summit slabs.

routes.name: Mikonui Spur
routes.description:
Head up the Mikonui Valley to the Mikonui–Dickson confluence and pick up the locally
maintained marked route a short way up the Dickson River. Follow this presently overgrown
permolat track up to the tops and Mikonui Spur Biv (DOC, two-person). The ridge above to Mt
Bowen offers reasonable travel with steep sections in the lower part. Higher up, an easy sidle on
the south-west side avoids the more difficult ridge crest.
routes.ascent: L H Parry, Ron Brown ( first known ascent), 15 November 1937

routes.name: South (Sentinel) Ridge to Noisy Basin and the Whitcombe Valley
routes.description:
Mt Bowen can be traversed with packs to the Whitcombe Valley. From Mt Bowen, the rocky
spur out past Sentinel Peak offers good travel down to J34 460909 / BV18 360 293, where there
may still be an old marker post. Easy tussock travel then leads left to Noisy Stream and Basin.
From the 1170-metre contour, leave Noisy Stream and sidle on the true left across benches and
basins to J34 474922 / BV18 374 306. Descend the spur over a lower knoll directly down to join
the marked route leading to the Whitcombe Valley. The lightly-marked route is followable with
care, but deteriorates on forested flats near the river.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/arthurs-pas.name: Mt Bowers
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/arthurs-pas.description: First ascended by E Wilson and A Anderson, December 1930.

routes.name: From Upper Edwards Valley
routes.description: A scramble from the upper valley floor.
routes.ascent: E Wilson and A Anderson, December 1930

routes.name: From East Edwards Valley
routes.description: Via a scree slide from the East Edwards Valley.

routes.name: Unnamed
routes.description: From the head of Gorilla Stream traverse the north ridge. Alternatively, climb from Chop Creek.
routes.ascent: Peter Graham, Jack Lippe, Dorothy Theomin, Apr 1916

routes.name: Normal Routes
routes.description: Climb from the north side of Fohn Saddle or from the north.

routes.name: North East Ridge
routes.description:
A long approach via Long Flat Creek leads up to the Main Divide. Sidle along 
the ridge turning problems on both left and right to reach a summit tower. 
Climb a chimney and loose blocks to gain the crest and the summit.
routes.ascent: Bill Beaven, Ian Gibbs, Norman Hardie, John Harrison, Jock Montgomery, January 1966

routes.name: South East Face
routes.description:
The first ascent of this peak was completed from the upper reaches of the 
Makarora River. Modern climbers can cross the ridge from the Brewster Glacier 
and follow a gully onto the crest.
routes.ascent: C.Bentham, Cyril Turner, Samuel Turner January 1929

routes.name: South West Face
routes.description:
From Brewster Hut sidle past Armstrong and Peak 2257 to reach the upper 
Brewster Glacier. Alternatively, from a camp on the Stey Brae ridge, traverse 
to the bottom of the face. A number of gully routes of moderate difficulty 
lead up to the crest. Move along the narrow summit ridge to the top. Descent 
is typically via a ridge and gully onto the south face, followed by a 
traverse back onto the Brewster Glacier.
routes.ascent: P.Berry, G.Crowley, Harry Dowall, V.Heine, R.G.Kulka, J.McKenzie, D.Scott and Colin Todd, October 1953

routes.name: West Ridge
routes.description:
Bush bash up Warden Spur and over Topheavy Peak then follow the broad ridge 
to the summit. The top section can be tricky when plastered with sastrugi. 
Alternatively, walk in via Brewster hut and traverse to glacier across rough 
ground. Traverse in between 1750-1800m alt to avoid dangerous gully. 5.5 hrs. 
Route across glacier and over triple pointed summit ridge 6 hrs return.
routes.ascent: Mick Bowie, H.G.Courtney, 1934

routes.name: From the Wills Valley
routes.description: Follow Fleming Creek and choose a route up either the east or west ridge.
routes.ascent: Descended by Bill Beaven, Ian Gibbs, Norman Hardie, John Harrison, Jock Montgomery, January 1966

routes.name: North Island Detox
routes.description:
Walk west under the south west face until 50-100m from the south west ridge. 
A slab of compact rock exists on the right hand side of a buttress. Climb 
this to the top of the ridge (grade 12, 2 pitches) and then scramble along 
the ridge to the summit. A much better route  in mid summer than the choss 
fest on the south west face.
routes.ascent: Rob Addis, Chris Peacock 2010

routes.name: Standard Route
routes.description: From the névé of the Explorer Glacier climb mixed ground (with rotten rock) to just south of the summit.
routes.ascent: Alex Graham, Henry Newton, Feb 1907.

routes.name: Main Divide Route
routes.description: The Divide ridge from Glacier Peak is a pinnacled, enjoyable climb. Also refer to Upper Tasman Glacier Section.
routes.ascent: Harold Porter, Vic Williams, Dec 1930 (from the east).

routes.name: From Whymper Saddle
routes.description: From Whymper Saddle follow the Main Divide firstly on snow then rock to the Low Peak.
routes.ascent: D W Beatty, P A L Fraser, A W McNaught, J V McNulty, Jan 1955 (Low Pk)

routes.name: South West Ridge
routes.description: The vague feature on the left side of the peak seen from Murchison Hut.
routes.ascent: John Gamlen, Keith McNaughton, Dec 1967 (Descended)

routes.name: Loves Last (South Face)
routes.description: Take the central gully and then enjoy ice on rock.
routes.ascent: Graham Love, Dave Carlyle, Sep 1985

routes.name: South East Ridge
routes.description: From Classen Saddle climb snow slopes to arrive high on the Main Divide north of the summit, then continue to the summit.
routes.ascent: First Ascent Unknown

routes.name: Main Divide
routes.description: From Classen Saddle traverse to the vicinity of Whataroa Saddle, then up south-eastern snow slopes (or rock depending on conditions) and then traverse the Main Divide to the summit.
routes.ascent: Will Kennedy, Jack Lippe, Jan 1917

routes.name: From Whataroa Saddle
routes.description: From Whataroa Saddle follow the rock and snow ridge of the Main Divide. Alternatively, turn to the western side and climb snow slopes that lead to a point north-east of the summit.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/canterbury/.name: Mt Brown
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/canterbury/.description: The central buttress on the south face of Mt Brown contains excellent quality rock, best viewed from the upper valley of Bush Stream.

routes.name: South West Face
routes.description: From the upper reaches of Bush Stream, plod up the scree slopes and scramble to the summit.
routes.ascent: Andy Macfarlane, 1995

routes.name: Actions Speak Louder
routes.description: This route on the central buttress on the south face has gained a reputation as one of New Zealand’s classic alpine rock routes. It begins at a higher level than the surrounding rock. Steep, awkward strata, overhangs and a prominent blackness make this the prominent line. Forcing past overhangs gives pause for thought on the first buttress. The second half of the route follows a prow up a series of towers. Pinnacles on the upper section were avoided on the right side during the first ascent but have been climbed direct (Bill McLeod, March 1996). Finish on the fangs. Truly a feast. Cruxes too numerous to mention.
routes.ascent: Ross Cullen, Bill McLeod, December 1995

routes.name: Mandate
routes.description: Beginning on a small block, climb a clean face on the left side of the south-east facing concave wall. Higher up, tend left to gain a grassy groove beneath the great black corner and head straight up. On reaching the terrace, head up ledges to gain the headwall. Follow the arrow-straight corner/crack system that runs on a slight diagonal the entire height of this wall. The rock is compact and solid, predominantly vertical, but can be damp in places. Requires a positive attitude.
routes.ascent: Bill McLeod, Chris Warburton, January 1997

routes.name: No More Words
routes.description: The route ascends an obvious feature – ‘The Rocket’ – on the right side of the bluff. Immaculate rock, few options, small gear protection, and the top three pitches are sustained grade 20 climbing.
routes.ascent: Bill McLeod, February 1995

routes.name: South East Ridge
routes.description: Climb the spur at BY15 654 394 through open beech forest to the tussock terrace (delightful camping). Follow the ridge, keeping the four tarns on your right, cut through the spur at BY15 633 414, and veer around to the summit knob.
routes.ascent: Noel Pullan, Diane Mellish, March 2002

routes.name: North Face
routes.description: Go up Freds Stream for 3.5km, climb the steepening tussock slopes to reach the alpine meadows, and plod to the summit.
routes.ascent: First ascent unknown

routes.name: South West Arête
routes.description:
From the central Foster Glacier take a snow route past Mt Marchant to gain 
the south west arête and from there, up to the summit.

Sixty four years later, a better approach appears to be via the snow slopes 
of the Foster Glacier aiming north of Mt Browning, to reach the main Divide, 
then easy travel south along the Divide to the summit.
routes.ascent: B.N.Challis, Lyn Challis, November 1938

routes.name: From the Hawkes Bay Glacier
routes.description: From the Hawkes Bay Glacier climb the north face to the summit.
routes.ascent: Phil Grover, Kevin Helm, John Nankervis, February 1983

routes.name: Unnamed
routes.description: Straightforward from the top of Gorilla Stream.
routes.ascent: Peter Graham, Dorothy Holdsworth, Irene Chambers, R B Seager, Mar 1917

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aoraki/godl.name: Bruce Murray
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aoraki/godl.description: On the ridge SE of Mt Moffat

routes.name: Unnamed
routes.description: The peak can be climbed from Panorama, from Elizabeth Glacier (gaining the col between the summit and Panorama) and from Easter Glacier.
routes.ascent: A J Scott, R H Booth, David Hall, Apr 1931

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/otago/barri.name: Bruce Pk
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/otago/barri.description:
Bruce Peak was named for Bruce Clark who died in 1984 in a fall on the north face during an alpine rescue practice on the mountain. Bruce was an experienced and talented climber who had contributed much to New Zealand climbing and Search and Rescue. His death starkly illustrated that mountains can be both beautiful and dangerous places. 
We had just finished a double rope lower and had packed up the gear, safety line last. It was warmer, the sun had shone for a while and it had stopped snowing. But as we moved to safe ground along a large sloping ledge, a gust of wind blew me off balance and I clutched at the low scrub. Then Chris screamed, 'Bruce, Bruce, Oh my God, Bruce!' and I turned to see a flash of blue fly through the air. Bruce was falling, rolling and tumbling, cartwheeling and turning, like an astronaut on a weightless space walk, only there was no lifeline. Suddenly it was cold again; Bruce was gone.
Simon Cox, New Zealand Alpine Journal, 1985.

routes.name: North Face
routes.description:
The most obvious ascent route is up the north rib, following a line just east 
of the prominent buttress which runs down toward the North Temple Stream.
routes.ascent: Ross Cullen, March 1989

routes.name: From Gunsight Pass
routes.description:
Angle right up an exposed bench to gain the west ridge then cheval along the 
ridge until easier ground leads to the summit.
routes.ascent: First ascent unknown

routes.name: Kea Arete
routes.description:
The obvious arete/spur between Gunsight Pass and Butterfly Buttress. 7 
pitches (60m rope) on good quality rock. Crux (grade 14) on pitch 2, 
otherwise consistent grade 10-12 climbing. Any tricky bits go slightly left 
of arete.
Kea Arete (red), Butterfly Buttress (yellow)
routes.ascent: Dagmar Linder, Colin Magee, Matt Quirke,  24 Nov 2004

routes.name: Rocky Road
routes.description:
Pitch1  -  Start on the right hand side of the snow slope, around 6 metres 
traverse then straight up the face. Grade around 15, 60 metres.
Pitch 2  -   Keep heading straight up the face. Grade around 16, 60 metres.  
Pitch 3  -  Keep following the crag and keep yourself on the face. Grade 16. 60 metres.
Pitch 4  -  Continue climbing on the face, a little bit slabby. Grade 17. 60 metres.
Pitch 5  -  Start traverse to the ridge; it's very short. Around 25 metres. Grade 15.
Pitch 6  -  Head straight up for around 10-15 metres then keep climbing on the left. Grade 17. 60 metres. 

Last 200 metres we decided to short rope using running belays. Grade around 13-14.
routes.ascent: Tony Burnell and

routes.name: Butterfly Buttress
routes.description:
Ascend the prominent south western buttress from its lowest point in the mid 
South Temple. Sustained grade12-14 climbing. 500m height  gain on excellent 
quality rock. Descent via Bruce -Steeple Col.
routes.ascent: Ross Cullen, Geoff Gabites, Bill McLeod, February 2002

routes.name: Like Moths to a Flame
routes.description:
Starts up S-shaped crack on buttress to the right of Butterfly Buttress. 
Follow crack (3 pitches, 17, 16,14)to crest of buttress - easy ground (10-12) 
to notch to cross Butterfly Buttress. Route wanders up easy ground (10-12) to 
snowfield in middle of face between Kea and Butterfly, then up 17 corner and 
onto easier ground to summit. About 12 pitches due to wandering nature of 
route. About 400m of climbing. Surprisingly decent rock.
routes.ascent: Graham Johnson and Allan Brent 28/12/14

routes.name: Via Brunner Col
routes.description: Traverse from Brunner Col
routes.ascent: Earle Riddiford, D Beaven, Bill Beaven, J Gummer, M Spencer, December 1946;

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/main-divide.name: Mt Bryce
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/main-divide.description: Southern Alps Ka Tiritiri O Te Moana

routes.name: North Ridge
routes.description:
From the head of the North Mathias River climb the Omatane Glacier to reach the start of the
North Ridge. A straightforward climb although the rock is loose in places.
routes.ascent: Roger Chester, Alan Willis, John Pascoe, December 1930

routes.name: South Ridge
routes.description:
From Unknown Col the ridge is broad at first but steepens below the summit and may require
a traverse right onto the face. This is a straightforward climb in good snow conditions but
involves some tricky loose rock in late season.

routes.name: East Ridge
routes.description:
From the upper Unknown Stream, follow a vague rock buttress to a high point immediately
north-east of a small col marking the foot of the East Ridge. Climb into the col then follow
the ridge to the summit. This is a straightforward climb in good snow conditions, but involves
some loose rock in late season.

routes.name: East Ridge from Brunswick Creek
routes.description:
Brunswick Creek provides straightforward access directly up the branch draining Mt Bryce.
Continue up scree to the south. From the upper Brunswick, fairly easy rock scrambling in late
summer leads up the north-east face.
routes.ascent: Andrew Buglass, 1988

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aspiring/we.name: Buchanan Pks
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aspiring/we.description: Above the Matukituki River near Lake Wanaka.

routes.name: Watchtower (South West) Ridge
routes.description: Gain the ridge from the upper Mueller Glacier north of the Watchtower (a prominent knob near Fyfe Pass was first climbed by Otto Frind and Conrad Kain in Feb 1914) via a short face climb. The upper ridge is complicated by awkward slanting rock. The rock steps can be best turned on the slabby western face. The eastern side tends to be rotten.
routes.ascent: H T Barcham, Ash Cunningham, A Witten-Hannah, December 1952

routes.name: South Face
routes.description: From the Welchman Glacier ascend the obvious ramp which angles from left to right directly under the summit. Finish up the rock rib to the summit.
routes.ascent: Brian Weedon, Richard Schmidt, April 1980;

routes.name: Welchman Glacier Route
routes.description: Ascend the glacier and up a couloir (sometimes cornice threatened) to an unnamed col. Then either follow the Main Divide to the summit or drop down onto the western slopes and ascend from there. It is also possible to cross to Bernard Col from the Welchman Glacier, but it is a longer climb. The Welchman Glacier route is the best means of descent from Mt Burns. Three or more abseils may be necessary to descend over a cornice at the top. (Bernard Col may present similar problems.)
routes.ascent: Peter Graham, Samuel Turner, March 1914

routes.name: McKerrow Face
routes.description:
Mt Burns is the highest peak between Mts Sefton and Aspiring. Beginning from 
the McKerrow Glacier, crampon up the west face directly to the summit. A 
superb viewpoint as the Mueller, Dobson, Landsborough, Karangarua and Douglas 
Valleys radiate from the peak.
routes.ascent: Bernard Head, Peter Graham, Darby Thomson, Lawrence Earle, Jack Clarke, Alec Graham, 1909

routes.name: North- West Ridge
routes.description: We’d expected the serrated rock crest of the upper ridge – with three prominent steps – to be the crux of the route, but just below the first rock step we discovered a snow slope on the north side of the ridge which appeared to offer an easy route all the way around the rock steps. This was partly disappointing, as the ridge crest itself would have made an impressive climb. A nor’wester was forecast to develop that afternoon however, so we decided to take the fast route and abseiled 20 metres onto the snow slope.
routes.ascent: Rob Frost and Kieran Parsons, December 2013

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/canterbury/.name: Mt Butler
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/canterbury/.description: Mt Butler was first climbed by the surveyor George Roberts in 1881.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/main-divide.name: Button Pk
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/main-divide.description:
‘A large heap of stones held together by fate and mutual goodwill’, wrote Deryck Morse, who also
noted that the rock on the route to Kea Pass, ‘holds together fairly well, so long as you don’t step on it’.

routes.name: From Harcourt Creek
routes.description: Easily approached up gravel and rock from the west.
routes.ascent: L Parry, 21 March 1936

routes.name: South Ridge
routes.description: Gain Kea Pass and then climb the ridge.
routes.ascent: G Auton, N Syme, A Wicks, E Wallace, December 1950

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/arthurs-pas.name: Mt Byrne
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/arthurs-pas.description: Mt Byrne is a peak near Locke Stream Hut on the upper Taramakau River

routes.name: Mt Byrne from Locke Stream Hut
routes.description: Follow Locke Stream well up until the scrub thins and then take the easiest looking gut on to the ridge South of Foy Pass. Then follow the rolling tussock ridge to the Summit ( which strangely is not quite the highest ground around!---you may miss it)

routes.name: North Ridge
routes.description:
The North Ridge can be reached via a steep hike from the upper Griffiths Stream to snow slopes
immediately south of Mt Scott.

routes.name: From Gifford Stream
routes.description:
Take the long spur from the valley floor to a narrow ridge of loose rock. Veer right, cross the
lower glacier and then follow steep rock to the higher glacier and finally rotten rock to the top.
routes.ascent: A G Bogle, C E Taylor, W Challis, April 1936

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aoraki/main.name: Cadogan Pk
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aoraki/main.description: Sefton Biv

routes.name: East Rib
routes.description: Via the rock ridge between the Eugenie and Hayter Glaciers and a rib right of centre on the East Face. A bad area for slab avalanches early in the summer.
routes.ascent: Freda Du Faur, Peter Graham, Mar 1913.

routes.name: From the Copland Pass
routes.description: From the Copland Pass
routes.ascent: Franz & Julius Malcher, E Ranft, Feb 1914.

routes.name: East Face
routes.description:
From the Ahuriri Valley negotiate some bluffs before cramponing up the slope 
to reach the east ridge leading to the summit.
routes.ascent: Lindsay Crozier, Jim Crozier, S.Rose, February 1939

routes.name: Taurus (East Face)
routes.description: 1500 metre from the valley floor to the summit. The first 200 metres and the final (rimed) 200 present the greatest challenges.
routes.ascent: Ross Cullen, Nick Shearer, April 2012

routes.name: From Harman Pass
routes.description:
Easily ascended from Harman Pass.
It is also possible to follow a route up the scree slide opposite Carrington Hut to the Southern Spur, which then leads to the summit.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/westland/mt.name: Mt Campbell
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/westland/mt.description: Between the Haast and Burke Rivers.

routes.name: North West Ridge
routes.description: A short rock ridge, which is not difficult from Griffiths Saddle.
routes.ascent: Roland Cant, Bill Cullens, March 1934

routes.name: From Gifford Stream
routes.description:
From Gifford Stream gain snow slopes on the east of the peak. From here several options exist
to the summit.

routes.name: East Face
routes.description:
Approach: Get here via the Donaldson, or via Pearl Drop Ice. For this approach, cross the Ice King Tops at the Eastern end, as per the Chasm Pass Route on Pollux (III,2). A recent (2020) ascent in late Summer did this by taking a long, unlikely looking diagonal ledge across a rock face (from the N end of the Pearl Drop Ice Basin), then continuing up and right on hanging snowslopes to gain the S ridge of pt 2239 above prominent gendarmes.  Easily up the ridge above then traverse the E Face pt 2239 (straightforward but exposed) to Hugh Ice.

Climb: Starting at the remnants of Hugh Ice, Steep scrambling on clean rock (good holds) leads up the E then lower angled NE slopes to the summit.
routes.ascent: Allan Brent, Ruari Macfarlane, Feb 2020

routes.name: From Two Thumb Stream
routes.description: Captains Peak and the nearby Point 2353m can be climbed directly from Two Thumb Stream via long scree slopes, or included as part of a ridge traverse.

routes.name: South West Ridge
routes.description:
From Kea Pass the South West Ridge is a straightforward climb, negotiating a rock step on the
north side of the ridge.

routes.name: North Ridge
routes.description: A straightforward ridge linking Mt Carl with Mt Frieda, first climbed on a traverse of the range.
routes.ascent: Roger Chester, December 1930

routes.name: South East Ridge
routes.description:
This ridge comprises very loose rock, which is difficult to negotiate unless covered with consolidated
snow. A lack of snow will increase the grade.
routes.ascent: Roger Chester, December 1930

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/arthurs-pas.name: Carrington Pk
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/arthurs-pas.description: Carrington Pk is an attractive peak seen from near the junction of the Waimakariri and White Rivers. It is a good climb from Waimakariri Falls Hut.

routes.name: South West Ridge
routes.description:
From the Waimakariri valley floor, follow the slope north of Campbell Creek 
up to the broad shoulder of the South West Ridge. Traverse it to the top or 
sidle across the south-east slopes and gain the ridge immediately below the 
peak. The final 100m of this ridge is very loose rock.

routes.name: North Ridge
routes.description:
Climbed by following the prominent Y-shaped gully through the bluffs at the 
base of the peak some 500m downstream of the Waimakariri Falls. This reaches 
the easier slopes below the summit’s North Ridge. The lower bluffs are very 
prone to rockfall.
routes.ascent: C Hilgendorf, December 1924

routes.name: Main Divide Route
routes.description:
Climb to the Main Divide opposite the hut (ascend scree/snow slopes just 
north of the small side stream above the hut, then move across sidling true 
right and up), and traverse it southwards to the summit. A traverse to Mt 
Armstrong is an available option.

routes.name: Carrington-Armstrong Traverse
routes.description:
On a good day this is well worth the effort. Ascend Carrington Pk, then the 
skyline traverse is a relatively straightforward affair. Descend easy slopes 
off Mt Armstrong to the col west of the rock bluffs.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/fiordland/d.name: Cascade Pk
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/fiordland/d.description: Bowen Valley

routes.name: South Ridge
routes.ascent: First ascent unknown.

routes.name: From Temple Basin
routes.description: Easy climbs from Temple Basin. Follow the Cassidy ski tow to gain the area south of Bill’s Basin.

routes.name: Via Cons Track
routes.description: Reached via Cons Track, which ascends on the Southwest Ridge from the Bealey River crossing on the Punchbowl Falls track. Once the bushline is reached continue ascending the ridge on loose rock. At the base of the bluffs, a rough trail sidles northwards ascending slowly under the bluffs. After 250 metres a steep scree gully is reached. Ascend this to the easier boulder slopes of the main ridge.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/main-divide.name: Cassino Pk
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/main-divide.description:
(Southern Grey Virgin).
Cassino, Alamein and Takrouna, were collectively known as the Grey Virgins.
Attempts to climb them were made over many years and they were among the last significant peaks in
the Alps to be climbed. Cassino Peak was originally climbed from the Grey Glacier along the South
Ridge. From the low summit, traverse under rock pinnacles and up the right-hand face to the summit
proper.
John Harrison, Ian Baine, B H (Snow) Williams, L G Osborne, 29 December 1952

routes.name: South Ridge
routes.description: Climb from the Grey Névé above the icefall to the hanging glacier. Then follow steep snow and rock to the Main Divide onto the low summit. Traverse under rock pinnacles between the summits and up the right hand face to the summit proper.
routes.ascent: John Harrison, Ian Baine, B H (Snow) Williams, Dec 1952

routes.name: From the West
routes.description:
From the lower Gino Watkins Glacier access the West Ridge. Up to the 2200-metre contour
this ridge has been used as access by climbing parties camping on the Nansen Glacier. From the
upper Nansen névé, climb the ridge to the summit.
routes.ascent: Laurie Osborne, Bruce Waterhouse, John Harrison, B H (Snow) Williams, Jan 1954

routes.name: North Ridge (Main Divide)
routes.description:
Climbed from the Nansen névé, approaching the peak from the north, mostly up the face.
On the first ascent a good snow lead took the party to the Main Divide North Ridge about
150 metres below the summit. Several pitches of mixed climbing led to the top. Descent via a
snowface and a couple of snow gullies back to the Nansen.
routes.ascent: John Nankervis, Phil Castle, Grant Stotter, Pat Thorn, Dec 1978

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aspiring/ma.name: Mt Castor
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aspiring/ma.description: This fine, rarely climbed peak just to the north of Pollux offers better climbing than its neighbour.

routes.name: Pickelhaube Glacier route.
routes.description: Follow the Bluffs route on Pollux and traverse below Pollux into the Pickelhaube Glacier. From there the South West Face is straightforward.
routes.ascent: The first ascent was made via Chasm Pass and the col between Pollux and Helena. C C Benzoni, L W Divers, R R & G L Edwards & D C Peters, March 1937.

routes.name: East Ridge.
routes.description: From the top of the moraine wall between Lake Lucidus and the North Wilkin, pick a line through the bluffs to gain a shelf that leads out to the lower East Ridge. Follow the ridge to the summit.
routes.ascent: Ian Baine & Graham McCallum. Dec 1963.

routes.name: South East Face.
routes.description: Gain the glacier above Lake Lucidus via the Bluffs route on Pollux. The route follows a prominent rock rib which merges into the snow of the face proper.
routes.ascent: Margaret Fyfe & Graham McCallum, Jan 1975.

routes.name: Pickelhaube Glacier from the Drake River
routes.description: From the Drake River sidle up the valley draining the Pickelhaube Glacier, to above bushline. Cut left up a scrub and tussock rib to slabs under Pegasus and follow benches to the Pickelhaube Glacier. Choose a route to suit up the last steeper bit.
routes.ascent: Matt Warwick & Geoff Spearpoint, Feb 1979.

routes.name: North Ridge
routes.description:
Make a rocky ridge scramble to the summit from either of the two cols to the north. Pinnacles
can be passed on either side of the ridge.

routes.name: West Face
routes.description:
Follow scree and snow-grass through small rock bluffs to reach the high basin immediately west
of Mt Caton, and pick a route through blocky, rocky terrain to the top.

routes.name: South West Ridge
routes.description:
This is a scree walk to the summit, reached as part of a ridge traverse or via scrambling through
small, loose, rocky bluffs directly up from Two Thumb Stream.

routes.name: North Ridge
routes.description:
A straightforward climb from Black Birch Creek. Alternatively, cross onto the western slopes
and follow these to the summit.
routes.ascent: Probably climbed by early shepherds and runholders, but also Peter Bain, Neil Payne,

routes.name: South West Ridge
routes.description:
Easy travel along the ridge over 2054m to reach the summit pyramid. A gully, 
then left ramp lead to easy ground and the  summit. Descent to the north to 
reach the  tarn at 1750m.
routes.ascent: Ross Cullen, Pip Lynch, April 2007

routes.name: West Peak (2499m) via South Col
routes.description: Climb to a col to the south of the peak and approximately 60m below the summit and follow the summit ridge. This is the route of the first ascent and appears more difficult today.

routes.name: West Peak (2499m) North Ridge
routes.description: Climb to the North Ridge to reach it at a nick above the gendarme. Follow the ridge to the summit, detouring as necessary mainly on the East Face.
routes.ascent: H.F. Wright and J. Robertson, Feb. 1914.

routes.name: Middle Peak (2450m)
routes.description: As for Mt Ferguson to the col, then from the col sidle down to a hanging valley at the head of Sixteen Mile Creek. From the hanging valley, scramble up to the glacier and col between the Middle and East Peak. From the col it is a short scramble up the east ridge to the summit.

routes.name: East Peak (2525m)
routes.description: As for West Peak until part way up the south summit ridge when steep slopes give access to a glacier to the east, or as for Middle Peak to glacier. Cross glacier to snow slopes leading up the south face of the East Peak to a col on the west side of the peak and from there along the summit ridge.

routes.name: From O’Leary Pass
routes.description: From O’Leary Pass via Frobisher.

routes.name: North Ridge. Grade
routes.description: Park Glacier provides access to the long summit ridge which is traversed by passing the gendarme on either the Beans Burn side or the Lake Unknown side. Alternatively, from the head of Lake Unknown, ascend through basins to about 1,920m then back along ridge. Ridge is quite narrow in places.

routes.name: South Ridge.
routes.description: Accessible from Park Pass and the Park Glacier or Lake Unknown.

routes.name: Uprising
routes.description: Supersedes and generally surpasses the first Charismatic route, while following a roughly similar line. 16–19 pitches. Double hangers are on belay only stations. Take about 15 draws, slings, full set of wires and cams up to #3 + a few extra wires and cams ≈ finger crack size. 2x 60m+ropes.
routes.ascent: Jon Sedon, Paul Rogers, Matt Evrard, Camille Berthoux, Bruce Dowrick, 27 December 2018

routes.name: Wild Dykes
routes.description:
Wild Dykes
650m , 24 pitches , 23

Rack 10-12 draws , single set nuts, single cams .2,2,3 doubles .3-1.
Established ground up over 3.5 days of climbing and five days total on the wall. The route can be rapped with a single 60m rope.
 
Approach via the first 7 pitches of Uprising.
 
Once reaching the upper wall move right past uprising along the ledge to a fixed rope. At the base of the route there are singular bivy spots for 3 people. A 20L water bucket is in place 2m above the ring bolt of the fixed line on a small ledge.
routes.ascent: Llewellyn Murdoch & Daniel Joll Feb 2022

routes.name: The Charismatic Movement Marketing Council
routes.description:
The face on the truncated spur on the true left, seen from the tunnel portal. Access to the base of the wall is difficult and thickly vegetated, but the quality of the rock on the upper walls is well worth the adventure.
14 pitches. Solid climbing around grade 20; some bolts and fixed gear. A possible bivvy ledge can be found at the top of the 4th pitch. The route was originally climbed over three weeks and involves a tricky approach from the Milford Road.
Haul up on tussock trending right, traversing right 100m below the wall to a flat-looking area with a few trees. A difficult and exposed section of cliff trends up and right to the start of the technical climbing. 
Paul Rogers and Gareth Sharp abseiled down the line and climbed the top six or so pitches, placing belay anchors. Paul placed a bolt on lead through the crux section, swearing: 'those f*ckers have sand-bagged me...'
Descent: nine or ten abseils. Pitches five and six would be difficult to retreat from without fixed lines but not impossible. Walking out to Homer via the ridge to Moir would be the best and safest option.
routes.ascent: Gwilym Griffith-Jones, Daniel Meecham, February 1994

routes.name: East Ridge
routes.ascent: Dal Ryan, 1960.

routes.name: Original Route
routes.description: From Monkey Creek
routes.ascent: Kurt Suter, Miss Cecily Ramsay, 1936.

routes.name: Bush Parkour
routes.description:
12 pitches.
Scramble up large left leaning ramp until it steepens
1,2: continue up ramp until it tops out
3: straight up corner then flake system towards base of snow field (17)
4,5: scramble around snowfield to base of upper wall
6: easy climbing up wall aiming towards long clean corner
7: continue up towards shallow groove below corner, hanging belay left of the 
base of groove (19)
8: traverse right and move up groove to awesome belay ledge at base of corner 
(crux)
9: up corner, moving onto arete via big flake (18)
10-12: continue up, aiming for rib leading to summit.
Scramble to summit

Excellent clean rock on upper half of face, good pro. Lots of potential for 
more lines, especially easier ones on the rh side of the face.
routes.ascent: Sam Waetford Kyle Walter Feb 2016

routes.name: The West Ridge.
routes.description: From Moncrieff Col traverse around the head of the Volta Névé beneath the ridge of the Main Divide before climbing about 100m of steep but easy rock to gain the upper shelf of the glacier. From the shelf good ledges lead up and east across the North Face of Scylla to give access to the col between Scylla and Charybdis. A short scramble on broken rock leads to the summit. The time to the top from Moncrieff Col is about five hours.
routes.ascent: Graham Bishop, Roger Barrowclough & Henry Stoddart, after an abortive attempt on Scylla, Dec 1961.

routes.name: CHEESEMAN SKI AREA TO MOUNT OLYMPUS, Ski Touring.
routes.description:
Grade 2					640 metres
The skifield of “Mount Cheeseman” is actually on the south-east slopes of Mount Cockayne – a mountain named after Leonard Cockayne (1855-1934), a well-known Canterbury botanist and conservationist. Cheeseman is a friendly little skifield, with 2 T-bar lifts, snow groomers and an on-snow accommodation lodge, and it’s a good alternative to Mount Hutt when skiing from Christchurch. Cheeseman sell single T-bar ride tickets to the top of the skifield for a modest $5, giving good access to backcountry basins. There’s a backcountry avalanche risk advisory board at the top of the lifts.
The large basin to the south of the ski area, in the headwaters of Tim’s Stream, is known as “Tarn Basin”, and is popular with skiers and boarders going out from the ski area. There are good turns to be had from the top of the lifts (1840m) all the way down to the 1500 metre level, or lower. Many people ski only as far as the frozen tarn at 1620 metre elevation, before returning to the ski area via a small col on the intervening ridge at 1760m.
To head towards Olympus and the Ryton Valley, tour south-west 2½ km along the ridge to the peak of Mount Cheeseman itself (2030m) in 75 to 90 minutes. Beware of cornices that often form on the eastern side of this ridge. There’s a good run off point 1950 east down into Tarn Basin, and also a nice basin to the west (the headwaters of Hut Creek), which sees a lot less traffic than Tarn Basin.
From the top of Mount Cheeseman itself, you look south-west into the undulating slopes of the upper Ryton Valley. Ski off the peak into the Ryton for 150 vertical metres, and then traverse to the skier’s right (west) to reach the central gully of the Ryton, which often holds lovely powder snow. This gully is a nice consistent 20º gradient down to flats at the 1420m level, i.e. a 600 vertical metre run from the top of Mt Cheeseman. 75-90 minutes skinning back to the top for another run down. You can spend a whole day here cutting fresh tracks and return to the Cheeseman ski area, or go on to the Mount Olympus ski area.
To Mt Olympus ski area from the peak of Mount Cheeseman, it is easy travel west on the ridge towards spot elevation 1836, and then across a broad saddle and then a gradual 200 metre climb SW onto the north shoulder of Mount Olympus at about 2000m. Depending upon snow cover, it’s a ski traverse or it may be a walk on rocky slopes to get around to the west ridge of Mt Olympus, where snow slopes lead down to the upper basins of Mt Olympus ski area. (Windwhistle Winter Sports Club). 7½km or around 3 hours from skifield to skifield direct.

routes.name: MOUNT CHEESEMAN TO MOUNT ENYS, Ski Touring.
routes.description:
Grade 2/3				900 metres
The ridgeline immediately south of Mt Cheeseman has a few rocky outcrops which interrupt progress, so drop into the upper Ryton for 150 vertical metres or so and regain the ridge near point 1959. Continue south along the ridge crest to Mt Izard (2019m), and  Mt Cloudsley (2107). From here to the summit of Mount Enys (2194m) the ridge is broader with easier travel. 8½km or around 3 to 4 hours from the peak of Mt Cheeseman to Mt Enys.
Skiing off Mt Cheeseman to the south-east takes you into the headwaters of Waterfall Creek for a ski descent of 500 metres or more. Similar basins exist to the south-east of Mt Izard (Long Creek) and Mt Cloudsley (Whitewater Stream). The climb back to the ridge should be straightforward. The slopes on the western side of the range, facing into the lower Ryton Valley, are often wind-blasted free of snow, or melted by the heat of the sun, and are usually only worth skiing in good mid winter conditions. Best travel is along the ridgeline, and if necessary sidling on the eastern side.

routes.name: South Face
routes.description:
Climb straightforward snow slopes from the head of Chevalier Stream to the short west ridge
and follow this to the summit.
routes.ascent: Bob Clark-Hall, J L (Pat) Clark-Hall, December 1941

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/nelson-lake.name: Mt Chittenden
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/nelson-lake.description: Fifteen Mile Spur

routes.name: North Ridge
routes.description: Via Hamilton River. Ascend through open forest north of the eastern feeder to a basin below point 2154m. Head south-southeast to a small saddle above, and follow the ridge to a prominent step below point 2154m. Climb the step direct or turn it on eastern slopes. Pleasant scrambling leads to the summit. Alternatively, descend from the small saddle, sidle eastern slopes, then climb directly to the summit.

routes.name: East Face
routes.description: Via Connors Creek.  Climb steep scrubby gullies or scree and tussock slopes to a basin on the east face, then directly to the summit. Alternatively, climb easy slopes to a basin south-east of the summit and onto the narrow south ridge.

routes.name: West Face
routes.description: Via Begley Creek. Climb up the waterfall creek west of the summit, and to a saddle on the south ridge. Follow the narrow ridge to the top.

routes.name: North Face
routes.description: A direct  ascent of the north face from the upper Ahuriri Valley.
routes.ascent: Peter Dickson, March 1993

routes.name: From Newton Pass
routes.description: From Newton Pass traverse the ridge to the summit.
routes.ascent: Frank Alack, H K Douglas, December 1935

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/fiordland/d.name: Mt Christina
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/fiordland/d.description: tba

routes.name: Original Route
routes.description: Start up Cirque Creek, ascending a steep tussock and scrub fan to below a large vertical bluff. Trend right on a long traverse crossing two sculptured watercourses. From here it gets a little tricky; ascend steep tussock directly up until a small terrace leads right to a large snow basin (avoid the temptation to head directly up as the terrain steepens dramatically) then continue traversing right into the centre of the face. Follow easy slopes to the ridge north of the summit.
routes.ascent: Bob Sinclair, Ken Roberts, Harry Slater, George Moir, Bill Grave, 1926

routes.name: Skyline Buttress
routes.description: The buttress is approached by sidling down from high on the Original Route.
routes.ascent: Austin Brookes, Roger McCurdy, Bev Noble, Rod McLeod, 1974

routes.name: The European Connection
routes.description:
Seven pitches. A ridge and face route on the skyline as seen from Homer Hut, 
on the rock spur west of the South West Ridge of Christina. There is an 
easier variant missing the grade 20 pitch: stick to the main chimney crack 
instead of traversing right.
routes.ascent: Greg Aimer, Dave Brash, Jurgren Besswenger, January 1990

routes.name: South West Face
routes.description: Climb the south side of a prominent gut above Lyttle's Flat and continue up scree and snow slopes to the col just north of the summit.
routes.ascent: Bill Gordon, Ralph Miller, Dal Ryan, 1957.

routes.name: South West Ridge
routes.description:
From the col northeast of the South Pk, climb a snow gully to join the South 
West Ridge on the right. The first ascent began by climbing the South West 
Ridge of the South Peak.
routes.ascent: Dave Vass, December 1989

routes.name: South Ridge
routes.description: Climb up the shingle to a waterfall which drops out of a prominent west-facing gut, easily climbed on the north side. Early season avalanche danger from the hanging glacier can be avoided by crossing to slabs on the true right. A steep band is crossed in the central section and the rock deteriorates towards the summit.
routes.ascent: Murray Jones, Harold Jacobs, Mar 1966.

routes.name: East Ridge
routes.description:
Above Camera Flat cross the river and climb a large fan, going round to the 
right and up a gully, then across a small spur. Descend to a second gully, 
moving diagonally right into the big gully which is followed to snowfields 
and the East Ridge. Drop onto the Marian Face below Pt 1983 and back to the 
ridge beyond.
routes.ascent: Ron Dickie, Harold Jacobs, 29 February 1964

routes.name: McLeod Route
routes.description:
On first reaching Lake Marian head up directly to the Marian Bluffs. Climb a 
short scrubby wall right of a small gut, gaining the terraces above. Continue 
up the grassy slopes and ribs, tending left at the top to avoid rock walls. 
The travel on these bluffs is made easy by plentiful stout snowgrass. The 
snow slopes above give simple access to the East Ridge, which is gained well 
above the East Peak for a straightforward approach to the summit.
routes.ascent: Bill McLeod, 1980

routes.name: Brookes Simpson
routes.description: Up the bluffs and snow directly above Lake Marian to the upper Marian Ridge.
routes.ascent: Austin Brookes, Archie Simpson, 1965

routes.name: Gordon Hall-Jones Miller
routes.description:
From the top of the highest snowgrass slope beyond the lake, climb up and 
sidle left around a waterfall basin to a gendarme at the foot of the summit 
snow-slopes. The first ascent party made the first traverse of Mt Christina.
routes.ascent: Bill Gordon, Gerry Hall-Jones, Ralph Miller, 22 January 1955

routes.name: Complete East Ridge
routes.description:
Cross the Lake Marian Track Bridge off the Hollyford Road and go directly through the forest to the base of the ridge. Follow a vegetated weekness left (south) under obvious cliff, then back right, then left again to reach the bush line (about 4 hrs). Then follow the ridge for about 9km to all summits.

The black cliff with slabby base that protects the final part of the E ridge to the true summit has yet to be climbed and has been bypassed by all known parties to the north.

There is a good bivy platform on the west side of the ridge about 200m N of the summit.
routes.ascent: Craig Jefferies, Steve Skelton, Kyle Walter 6 Feb 2021

routes.name: East Ridge
routes.description:
Commence as for the South Ridge but cross the gut and move right, reaching 
the East Ridge at about 1800m. The first ascent party descended onto the 
Marian slopes to bypass Pt 1983, regaining the ridge to reach the East Pk. 
The East Pk is Pt 2185, not Pt 1983 as shown on the topomap.
routes.ascent: Bill Gordon, Morrie Davis, Duncan Wilson, Lloyd Warburton, February 1954

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/fiordland/d.name: Mt Christina North Pk
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/fiordland/d.description: Mt Christina’s North Pk is shown as Pt 2324 on Topomaps, but is probably better attributed to Pt 2284.

routes.name: McCallum Miller
routes.description:
Follow the rock buttress from upper Cirque Creek on the left side of a gully, 
crossing to the right and up a snow couloir higher up to gain the North 
Ridge. Reasonable rock, but grassy.
routes.ascent: Graham McCallum, Ralph Miller December 1962

routes.name: The Troubled Land
routes.description:
Long mellow sections of narrow couloir with frequent steps to the snowfield. 
Move right and finish up the couloir of the Miller McCallum line.
routes.ascent: Guy Mckinnon, September 2012

routes.name: Gully to North Peak
routes.description:
Starting as for the Original west face route until the first cleft, moving 
into a broad gully where possible. The route trends left out of the gully at 
points to avoid steep ground but never strays from it entirely. At about half 
height traverse some bulges, committing moves left, before regaining the 
gully and summit. A long 1200m ice climb. Descend via the Original Route; 
note that this involves tricky route finding and unstable snow late in the 
afternoon. "For my level of fitness and understanding of the Darrans this 
route was probably pushing it a bit. Diving home I woke up hitting marker 
posts and had to sleep a few times. Looking back with a bit more knowledge I 
probably had trashed blood sugar levels and was a bit hypothermic.“ – 
Merv English.
routes.ascent: Merv English (solo), November 1976

routes.name: Sea of Tranquillity
routes.description:
Five pitches: 17, 16, 17, 18, 17. Climb the standard route out of Cirque 
Creek to the high basin left of the Skyline Buttress. To reach the start, 
head leftwards up into a rocky gully to the base of the West Face. You will 
see a pillar towering over the top of the gully. Climb up and right over this 
pillar and move rightwards along a ledge system, bypassing a wide crack until 
reaching a nice hand-crack approximately 3m further on. Angle towards the 
V-groove you’ll have seen from down in the gully. Sensational 40m pitch.
routes.ascent: Steve Carr, Andrew MacFarlane, Des Smith, February 2000

routes.name: Gauloise Falls
routes.description:
The arty cascades that you scuttle around in summer on the way up Christina. 
Four pitches. Two pitches had amazing clear ice, so it felt like climbing 
directly on top of the rock and tussock. Descend by rapping off of the top 
pitch, and then sidle off the ledges on the true right. The winter of 1992 
was exceptionally cold and these falls froze good and solid. They may not 
form that often.
routes.ascent: Brian Alder, Matt Evrard, Dave Fearnley, July 1992

routes.name: South Face
routes.description:
Climb up a large shingle fan, then a gut leading to the foot of the South 
Ridge. Follow the rib on the true left of the gut. Early season snow provided 
good access to the col north of the South Peak and then to the summit. Jones 
and Laing then continued to the High Pk via the South West Face.
routes.ascent: Howard Laing, Murray Jones, November 1966

routes.name: South West Ridge
routes.description:
From the bottom of Lyttle's Flat climb a gully onto the ridge just left of 
the rock scar. Follow the ridge to the first rock band, ascend the prominent 
white buttress on the left of the rock band, then move up right, keeping to 
good rock. Join the ridge at a short corner and cheval, and continue to the 
South West Peak. The first ascentionist continued up the South West Ridge to 
the summit of the High Pk.
routes.ascent: Dave Vass, December 1989

routes.name: North Face
routes.description: From the Barkley Glacier, ascend a couloir to the low point in the ridge and climb the ridge, which is at first pinnacled and then rises steadily. The rock is loose.
routes.ascent: Mike Andrews, Donald Cargo, Feb 1973 (Descended).

routes.name: North Face
routes.description: From the left side of the top of the Barkley Glacier head up a small ice ramp to the main North Face. Ascend this to join the top of the NW ridge.
routes.ascent: S Hancock, T Murray, Jan 1988.

routes.name: North West Ridge
routes.description: Reached from the Barkley, Langdale, or Walpole Glaciers, the ridge turns into a pleasant snow arête which leads high onto the mountain and is followed by a short stretch of rotten rock to the summit. A good descent route.
routes.ascent: Hugh Chambers, Freda Du Faur, Jim Murphy, Jan 1911.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aoraki/malt.name: Mt Chudleigh Middle Pk
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aoraki/malt.description: The Middle Peak was first climbed by Alex Graham, Peter Graham, Ebenezer Teichelmann, Feb 1910 via the Reay Glacier Route

routes.name: Left Side of Buttress
routes.description: Ascend poor rock on the left side of the buttress that leads up to the summit ridge just left of the Middle Peak.
routes.ascent: Roger Foley, Simon Carr, Jan 1984.

routes.name: From Lecky Glacier
routes.description: From the Lecky Glacier. Ascend toward Reay Col but 200m below the Col head straight up steep snow, keeping left of some icecliffs to join up with the Reay Glacier route on Mt Chudleigh.
routes.ascent: B Barton and others, Jan 1974

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aoraki/malt.name: Mt Chudleigh South Pk
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aoraki/malt.description: Also known as the Low Peak.

routes.name: West Face
routes.description: From the Walpole Glacier ascend the rock face to the summit.
routes.ascent: I B Pledger, K Suter, P C Weenink, Dec 1934.

routes.name: West Ridge
routes.description: If climbed from the corner of the Walpole Valley the ridge provides a varied fare of rock climbing over pinnacles, across chevals, and up short walls. The rock is variable and in places offers some difficult moves. The final rise to the South Peak is up short slabs interspersed with ledges. The climbing here is easier than lower on the ridge.
routes.ascent: C Lake, R Thompson, Feb 1976.

routes.name: Reay Glacier Route
routes.description: Ascend the Reay Glacier keeping on the right until overlooking the Murchison Valley and then up easy snowslopes to the South Peak. A quick and easy descent route.
routes.ascent: Alex Graham, Peter Graham, Ebenezer Teichelmann, Feb 1910.

routes.name: North Ridge
routes.ascent: Gerry Hall-Jones, Duncan Wilson, Lloyd Warburton, 1955.

routes.name: From the Thomson Valley
routes.description:
From the Thomson valley near point 1132m choose a line up the slopes to reach 
the Foster Glacier and climb past active ice and crevasses to reach the 
summit pyramid and climb the rock to the summit.
routes.ascent: A.Hines, Athol Roberts, T.R.Smith, K.F.Wood December 1947

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aspiring/fo.name: Mt Clarke
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aspiring/fo.description: First climbed by L.M. Earle in 1909 from the Rees.

routes.name: North East Ridge.
routes.description: Climbing from Shelter Rock Hut follow the long couloir on the east face and complete the climb up the North East Ridge.

routes.name: South Ridge
routes.description:
From the Rees climb the Clarke Slip to gain the Clarke spur (or reach it from the north branch of Hunter Creek). Either ascend the spur to the summit, or detour on to the snow slopes to the west or cross the snow slopes to Pyramid Col and complete the climb by that ridge. Many variations are possible.

There is a small bivvy rock on the ridge out of the Clarke Slip at E40 509 150 but it is not much good in rough weather.

routes.name: Standard Route (West Ridge)
routes.description: The west ridge is easily reached from Twenty Five Mile Saddle. Access is through forest from Slip Flat then a long sidle on open tussock slopes, or via Twenty Five Mile Creek. Either way, you'll be on Rees Valley station land the whole way to the summit, and permission for access is required from the station (see notes above).

routes.name: From Drake Valley.
routes.description: Climbed from Drake Valley.
routes.ascent: A Cunningham & G J McCallum, Dec 1950.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/canterbury/.name: Cloudy Pk
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/canterbury/.description: Cloudy Pk is the highest point on the Cloudy Peak Range and is host to some excellent alpine rock climbing. The routes on the Left Hand Wall are listed here.

routes.name: North Ridge
routes.description:
This ridge cannot be soloed without a rope, there's a serious notch in the 
ridge that cannot be downclimbed safely.
routes.ascent: Bryan Barrer, Frank Askin, Dec 1931

routes.name: Golly Rodger
routes.description:
Left Wall
‘The route offers consistent climbing and has a worthwhile feel about 
it,’ said one of the first
ascentionists. ‘We were scared pretty much the whole time,’ said the 
other. Nine pitches on very
compact and sparsely protected rock. Belay/abseil bolts.
Access by scrambling up towards highest rock mound beneath centre of face. 
This is about 100 metres right of the big right-facing corner. Rather than 
climbing to top of the mound, move left about 40 m along ledges to bolt belay 
on nose of rock.
The first ascent climbed using all natural gear with the abseil bolts being 
added to the belay stances on the descent, which also helps to mark 
where the route goes.
routes.ascent: Peter Dickson, Bill McLeod, 1992

routes.name: The Groke
routes.description:
Left Wall. Generally follow the vague weaknesses just left of the obvious 
drainage line on the face. Even so, protection and belay anchors are sparse 
on some pitches, though belays are generally on good ledges. Some pitch 
descriptions are generalised.
routes.ascent: Fiona Bowie, Richard Thomson, 1987

routes.name: The Whole Nine Yards
routes.description:
A climb that goes from the bottom of the Hourglass Wall to the top of The Great Prow.  You have to walk a short distance, from the top of the tier above the Hourglass Wall to the base of the Prow Wall.  All belays are equipped with rings making it possible to rappel the route.   The Prow Wall section is Ok, but the upper Hourglass Wall has diagonal, leftward rappels which are moderately difficult. 
Take a comprehensive rack of cams between BD #0.3-#3 and a single set of wires. 
The most practical descent route is to abseil down the upper section to the base of The Great Prow, and using the access way down the big shelf to near the start of the SW ridge.
routes.ascent: Grant Piper, Bernie Frankpitt and Greg Low 2021 ,  prow section still to do (but open)

routes.name: South West Ridge
routes.description:
Start just left of the ridge : scramble up a gully to a small left-facing corner opposite a prominent
corner with a chimney. About four pitches of steep climbing, then a scramble to the summit of
Cloudy Peak. Alternatively, traverse right and descend scree.
routes.ascent: Jack Hill, Rob Rainsbury, 1974

routes.name: East Flank
routes.description:
From the Clyde, head up a gully south-east of Mt Nolan and cross into the basin east of Cloudy
Peak. Head directly towards the peak, swinging south onto the range at a flat area at 2120 metres
(also readily reached from Cloudy Peak Stream), before continuing up small bluffs then scree.

routes.name: South East Ridge
routes.description:
From the col between Cloudy Peak and Ferrar Peak (2120 meters), scramble up a 
broad ridge which gets easier and more defined the closer you get to the 
summit. If descending in poor visibility, care needs to be taken route 
finding to reach the col.
routes.ascent: FA Unknown

routes.name: Silver Lining
routes.description:
A line on the right hand end of the upper wall. Fine splitter cracks up steep 
terrain. After 3 excellent pitches can continue scrambling up SW ridge to the 
summit, or descend as per SW ridge.
routes.ascent: S Fortune, J Grinsted, S Chand, Feb 2017

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/canterbury/.name: Mt Coates
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/canterbury/.description: Named after Joseph Gordon Coates, the first New Zealand-born citizen to become Prime Minister.

routes.name: North Ridge
routes.description: A straightforward climb from Separation Col. Alternatively, ascend snow slopes from the confluence of the Separation and Butcher Glaciers to join the south-east ridge close to the summit. Coates can also be climbed from Twilight Col.
routes.ascent: Edgar Williams, A J Scott, R H Booth, Jan 1932

routes.name: South East Ridge
routes.description:
From the col at Pt 2094 metres (see Twilight Col) it is a slow climb on mixed snow and
rock along the ridge to the summit.
routes.ascent: David Hall, John Rogers, December 1950

routes.name: BROKEN RIVER TO CHEESEMAN SKI AREA, Ski Touring.
routes.description:
Grade 1/2							380 metres
From the top of the main rope tow at Broken River, put on skins and travel south-west along the undulating ridge – over Sunny Peak, on to the spot elevation 1884, and continue to another small bump (K34: 018850), where the ridge to Mount Wall heads east. Approximately 30 minutes from Broken River ski area, the day lodge of which is still visible.
The basin that descends to the NE of here is known as “Yukon bowl”, and is a pleasant 240 vertical metre ski descent down to a flat area where skins can be re-applied for the climb back out. There are steep rocky slopes below here, and on either side, so going back up the fall line is the best option, rather than trying a short cut return directly towards Broken River.
From 018850, to go on to Mount Cheeseman, ski down the main ridge to the south-west and skin up, over the point marked 1834 and then a few zig-zags up the north ridge of Mount Cockayne, which overlooks the Mount Cheeseman skifield. 3.5 km and 75 to 90 minutes in total from Broken River to Cheeseman Ski Area. In reverse, similar times from Cheeseman to Broken River.
A ski descent can be made SW off point 1834 into the headwaters of Cockayne Creek, if snow conditions suit.

routes.name: From Huxley-Hunter Col
routes.description:
Bob Cunningham, Peter Barker and John Chivers crossed the Huxley-Hunter 
saddle in December 1958, climbed College Peak 2330m and found a note on top 
saying it had been climbed by three Victoria College people in 1948.

routes.name: Seeing Eye
routes.description:
This 500 m high west face route is accessed by crossing the Main Divide from 
the South Huxley Valley, and descending into the upper Hunter Valley. Begin 
in centre of concave face. The crux wall is encountered at about one third 
height. Above a corner system the route leads up the prow of the buttress, 
and goes all the way to the summit. Mainly grade 13-14, crux pitch about 
grade 17.
routes.ascent: Bill McLeod, February 1996

routes.name: West Face
routes.description:
The west face has been climbed after access gained via the South Huxley 
Valley.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/main-divide.name: Commodore Pk
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/main-divide.description: Commodore Peak was referred to as Commodore Ridge on maps until about 1970.

routes.name: South West Ridge
routes.description: A straightforward traverse from Mt Ambrose along the South West Ridge.

routes.name: East Ridge
routes.description:
From Clarkes Pass, climb tussock and minor bluffs along the Divide, veering left onto a shoulder
east of Commodore Peak. Cross snow basins and ribs beyond, then climb to the summit.
routes.ascent: P Phipps, c 1934

routes.name: North Ridge
routes.description: A straightforward climb, loose in places.
routes.ascent: Roger Chester, John Pascoe, December 1930

routes.name: East Ridge
routes.description:
The East Ridge was originally reached from Canyon Creek and is a straightforward climb to
the top, loose in places.
routes.ascent: Roger Chester, John Pascoe, December 1930

routes.name: From Harris Saddle
routes.description: A popular side trip from Harris Saddle on the Routeburn Track, with good views of the Hollyford valley and Darran Mountains.

routes.name: South Ridge
routes.description: Climb the slopes of the Surprise Glacier to Godley Pass and then ascend the South Ridge. The South Ridge can be accessed nearer to Conrad by climbing the gully immediately north of Whispering Falls, and following a snow basin to the South Ridge. Alternatively, traverse from Armadillo Saddle or a point nearer the peak (two rock steps near the summit offer good quality climbing).
routes.ascent: Conrad Kain, Otto Frind, Jan 1914

routes.name: West Face
routes.description: Warm and pleasant rock slabs.
routes.ascent: Shelley Hersey, Paul Hersey, Jamie Vinton-Boot, January 2012

routes.name: North Ridge
routes.description: Start on rock from the Harper Glacier under Armadillo Saddle. In good snow conditions sidle under the ridge to Conrad, gain access to the peak roughly 200m from the summit.
routes.ascent: K Wade, I Dainis, Jan 1965 (Descended)

routes.name: East Ridge
routes.description: Climb from Rutherford Stream.
routes.ascent: Philip Temple, Brian Turner, Jan 1977

routes.name: Original Route
routes.ascent: Erskine Bowmar, Chally Bowmar, J Dickie, K Cochrane, Dec 1932.

routes.name: Via Bristol Top or Frenchay Col.
routes.description: Follow the Main Divide from either Bristol Top or Frenchay Col. Conway itself is just off the Divide to the west.
routes.ascent: Frank Milne, Harold Porter, Mar 1925.

routes.name: East Ridge
routes.description: From the Franz Josef Névé ascend to Frenchay Col (2685m) and up the Main Divide ridge before turning northwest and up to the summit.
routes.ascent: Ida Corry, Mark Lysons, Jan 1933

routes.name: Explorer Glacier via Bristol Top
routes.description: From Bristol Top head along the pinnacled Main Divide and onto the summit just off the Divide.
routes.ascent: Alex Graham, Henry Newton, Feb 1907.

routes.name: Sunshine Buttress
routes.description:
This route is on the buttress to the right of Moonshine Buttress. Six or so pitches of grade 17 climbing on good rock. A small section of argillite needs care but it does not detract from
the overall good experience. The final pitch is 50m at grade 17.
routes.ascent: Craig Cardie, Allan Uren, 2004

routes.name: The Vision III, 7+
routes.description:
The gully line on the left-hand edge of the
buttress. Six pitches that require a variety of fixed
gear. The crux is at pitch four with a problematic
rock step corner. The first ascent went up the
thin crack on the right and used a few points
of aid. Kester Brown and Jono Clarke climbed
the overhanging corner free—hard technical
climbing (M6) and runout to where the roof joins
the corner. The route does form as a big white-ice
line—in those conditions you’ll wonder what all
the fuss was about.
routes.ascent: FA: Adrian Camm, Johnny Davison, Julian White, Allan Uren, winter 2006

routes.name: Life in the Fridge III, 4+
routes.description:
This is a variant of The Vision. At the crux of The
Vision head right up a leaning ramp.
Johnny Davison, Allan Uren, Aug 2006
routes.ascent: Johnny Davison, Allan Uren, Aug 2006

routes.name: Technospectacle III, 8
routes.description:
A line of ‘most resistance’ taking a devious
line on the face to link up three sections of
difficult mixed ground. The first two pitches are
straightforward gully climbing. The third pitch
through a rock band is tricky to protect, but not
the crux. The fifth pitch is the crux (M7) and starts off the ramp of Life in the Fridge. It climbs
a thin finger of ice and bare rock—a serious lead.
One more pitch to the ridge, finishing at the top
of The Vision.
routes.ascent: Jono Clarke, Jamie Vinton-Boot, Aug 2011

routes.name: The Grey Hare
routes.description:
5 pitch ice, snow, and mixed route that starts off in the corner just left of the slabby rock (of the buttress to the right of Moonshine buttress,) and goes up a corner/chimney. The route can be taken up to the saddle in 4 pitches or you can take an alternate end and go right up the obvious gullies for a bit more ice/mixed fun. Bring your snowstake for getting off the sloping top.

P1: 30m WI2+ to the bottom of the steep traversing bulge. You can use the chimney to lay back against.
P2: 55m WI2+ with WI3 crux. Tackle the crux and move into the left gully. This takes you up to the snow slopes.
P3: 60m WI2+ more blue ice up the gully until you come out to the snow slope, find some ice to belay off.
P4: 60m 60 degree snow slope, may be iced up in different conditions.
P5: 60+m WI2+ M3/4 Ice runnels up between mixed ground. Mostly M3 with some M4 moves. Tops out on the snow slope or build a rock belay before topping out.
routes.ascent: Jacob Downie, Evan Davies, Sept 8, 2018.

routes.name: Standard Route
routes.description: An easy climb from all directions: from Starvation Saddle, the Mannering Névé or via number of options from the slopes above Murchison Hut.
routes.ascent: M Barford, J Moore, Dec 1943

routes.name: Unnamed
routes.description: Gain the saddle east of the peak from either the Aida or Harper Glaciers. More direct routes from the Murchison Glacier exist.
routes.ascent: S Drake, W F Crawshaw, David Hall, Jan 1947

routes.name: Standard Route
routes.description: As for Brenda Peak, then from Brenda Peak.

routes.name: From the Tasman Glacier
routes.description: From the Tasman Glacier, ascend the East Ridge up a snow and rock ridge until a broad plateau. From here ascend either to the summit direct or gain the ridge south of the summit. This is a good descent route.
routes.ascent: Peter Graham, Claude Macdonald, Jim Murphy, Feb 1909.

routes.name: Via the Divide Ridge
routes.description: Via the Divide Ridge from Climbers Col, ascend a mixed snow and ice ridge with rock of varying quality. Traverse any difficulties on the west.
routes.ascent: Graham McCallum, H P Barcham, P C Gardiner, J B Waterhouse, Dec 1954

routes.name: Edwards Face
routes.description: Climb onto the Edwards Glacier névé from the Spencer Glacier. From the névé follow a prominent couloir onto the Divide to reach a small rock peak well south of Climbers Col. Follow the Divide south to Coronet.
routes.ascent: Dave Bamford, Peter Fullerton, George Kendall, John Nankervis, Jan 1978.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aspiring/ba.name: Cosmos Pks
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aspiring/ba.description: The Cosmos Peaks exist in a Pounamu Special Permit Area.

routes.name: From the Dart
routes.description: From the Dart, climb Slip Stream until the ledges west of and above Lake Mystery can be traversed to a snowfield from which a steep couloir leads to the summit. A rocky ridge from the same snowfield leads to the higher West Peak. Good camp spots at E40 376 158.

routes.name: From Beans Burn
routes.description:
Access to the peaks can be gained from the true left of the Beans Burn at the first open flat, from where a creek may be followed to the snowline and the jagged peaks, or cross Beans Burn at E40 349 136 and climb to bushline.
Direct access can be gained from Sandy Flat in the Dart.

Follow Beans Burn to point E40 349 136, cross the Beans Burn and follow deer tracks to the top of the bushline. Head up a prominent gully which gains access to the south end of the snowfields from where the summits can be gained.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/nelson-lake.name: Cotterell Pk
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/nelson-lake.description: St Arnaud Range

routes.name: East Face
routes.description: Via Hamilton River. Climb easy tussock and scree slopes to the summit.

routes.name: South East Ridge
routes.description:
From Hamilton River. 
A striking ridge gained from the saddle at 1675m to the Begley. Steep towers can be turned via western slopes.

routes.name: South Face
routes.description: Via Begley Creek. A narrow steep gully (visible from the flat just downstream of Begley Hut) angles up right from the bottom of the face to the South East ridge. Take the left exit option, and follow the ridge (or a slope on the north side) to a knob south-southeast of the summit, then cross a basin to the summit ridge. A more technical variation is to climb part way up the gully, and then sidle left across a steep snow-covered slab and up a snow slope to a blocky rib. The easiest descent (or ascent) route is via a large basin and gully south-west of the peak.

routes.name: North West Face Route
routes.description: Cross the river just below John Tait Hut (Travers Valley), and follow downriver a short distance to a bush spur leading above the bushline to scree basins. Steep gullies lead to the ridge north of the summit.

routes.name: South West Ridge
routes.description: The scree basin of North West Face Route (Travers Valley), leads to a col;  the final 60m of rock ridge is interesting.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/canterbury/.name: Couloir Pk
