https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/lewis-pass-.description: An outlier of the Nelson Tops, above Lake Sumner and the Hurunui River.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/fiordland/d.name: Mt Madeline
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/fiordland/d.description: Madeline is a popular climb from Turners Biv and a much less committing proposition than Tutoko. The first mountaineering party to venture into the Tutoko valley was that of Malcolm Ross, Kenneth Ross, W J Hodgkin and Tom Fyfe, in 1895. They claimed to have made the first ascent of Tutoko, but actually climbed the low (west) peak of Madeline.

routes.name: South West Face
routes.description: From the Madeline Snowfield climb the snow face and finish on the upper South Ridge. The ridge can be reached sooner, at about 2200m, for a more challenging climb. The South West Face was used in the first traverse of Madeline on 16 January 1955, by Bill Blee, Ron Dickie, Bill Gordon and Ralph Miller. They descended the top of the North East Ridge and traversed the snow shelf on the north side of the peak back to Turners Pass. Jim Strang, Bruce Clark and Paul Corwin made the first winter ascent (IV, WI2).
routes.ascent: Alf Cowling, Samuel Turner, March 1920

routes.name: Mad Line
routes.description: A good route with a fun rock climb leading directly to the west summit of Mt Madeline. Access the rock ridge by climbing nearly to Turner Pass (the col east of Pt 2119) either from the Madeline Snowfield or slabs above the Age Glacier.
routes.ascent: Steve Skelton, Justin Venable, Simon Rutherford, December 29 2016

routes.name: North West Buttress
routes.description: Climb the rock ridge from Turners Pass.
routes.ascent: Margaret Clark, Jim Clark, G D Cowie, December 1958

routes.name: North East Ridge from Glacier Creek
routes.description: From the Donne Lake outlet, take easy slopes up and then left of the bluffs to gain the broad snow shelf and then the upper part of the North East Ridge.
routes.ascent: R Offer, G Mason, A Witten-Hannah, December 1953

routes.name: North East Ridge
routes.description: The full North East Ridge is a long climb. Start from the Hollyford Valley and head up Madeline Creek to gain the ridge just beyond the bushline. The first ascent traversed the mountain to Turner’s Bivvy and the Tutoko Valley.
routes.ascent: Ian Brown, Tom Williams, February 2009

routes.name: Standard Route
routes.description: Via the ridge behind the Hooker Hut or traverse from the Copland Pass.
routes.ascent: Jack Clarke, J E Walker, Hugh Wright, Jan 1911.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/nelson-lake.name: Mt Magdalene
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/nelson-lake.description: Ella Ra

routes.name: Downie Creek Route
routes.description: A marked track (overgrown but okay to follow) exists up Downie Creek to campsites near the bush edge. Mt Dorothy is an easy climb from the head of the creek. Mt Magdalene is a pleasant climb up a prominent scree/snow gully to the leading ridge and a rocky knoll at the top.

routes.name: Via Teichelmann
routes.description: Traverse a sharp arête out to a prominent rock tower (not the summit), then down and along another sharp arête. A longer climb than it looks.
routes.ascent: Harry Ayres, Bruce Gillies, D G Herron, Ed Hillary, Feb 1955.

routes.name: South Face
routes.description: Ascend a prominent rib that starts from the névé below the summit and leads out to the right of the summit. A short wall in the middle of the rib can be turned on the left. First climbed when well covered in snow.
routes.ascent: Gordon Hasell, E R B Graham, T A Nuttall, Jan 1957.

routes.name: Beuzenberg/ Braun-Elwert
routes.description: Traverse a sharp arête west from Mt Teichelmann to a prominent rock tower (this is not the summit), then down and along another sharp arête. Other than abseiling the "Anyone Can Play Guitar" Route  into the Balfour, this is the easiest way off Magellan. Also see the Via Teichelmann Route.
routes.ascent: Erica Beuzenberg, Gottlieb Braun-Elwert, Jun 1989.

routes.name: Outlier Buttress
routes.description: This peak is higher in altitude than Mt Magellen and has a decently hard route from the Balfour side to confirm that it is an fact a genuine peak by itself.
routes.ascent: Merv English, Peter Hillary, Nov 1976.

routes.name: Balfour Buttress
routes.description: Start at the toe of the buttress, beside an icefall, or from ramps to the right (which lead from the Magellan-Drake snow apron). Sustained climbing on excellent rock leads up with the climb slowly relenting (crux grade 15). Descend by either abseiling the " Anyone Can Play Guitar" Route or traverse to Teichelmann.
routes.ascent: Stu Allan, Jim Jolly, Feb 1976.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/nelson-lake.name: Mt Mahanga
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/nelson-lake.description: Southern end of the Mahanga Ra, possibly in the Spenser Mts.

routes.name: North Face
routes.description: Above Lake Constance follow the West Sabine to a basin and a long scree fan. Climb carpetgrass and moderate rock beside a small gorge and traverse to a tussock shelf (or follow the Sabine true left, and to the right of bluffs, onto the shelf). Head south-west towards a col, and then the north ridge (very loose) to the summit pyramid.

routes.name: East Ridge
routes.description: From Waiau Pass the ridge is broad and easy, later narrowing. When an impassable notch is reached, descend south to a shelf and regain the ridge higher up. The remainder of the ridge is pinnacled.

routes.name: South East Face
routes.description: From near the bottom of the Waiau Pass route and the Waiau River, a tussock spur leads to a scree basin south-east of Mahanga. The East Ridge is gained from a snow face.
routes.ascent: James Park and party, 1884

routes.name: North Ridge
routes.description: Traverse north across the Iso and Dipso Glaciers at about the same level as the hut, until the col between Skyscraper and Mainroyal is reached. A few minutes easy climbing up the rocky ridge leads to the summit, about 2.5 hours from the Colin Todd Hut.
routes.ascent: Paul Powell, Leo Faigan, Jack Ede, Gerry Wall, December 1948

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aspiring/sn.name: Maiti-iti
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aspiring/sn.description: Maiti-iti was first climbed by Lindsay Bruce, Alex Gourlay, and Les and Doug Brough from the Snow-White Glacier in January, 1958. The first ascent from the Dart was by Laurie Kennedy and Bruce Robertson, who traversed from Maori in February, 1966.

routes.name: Standard Route
routes.description:
A direct snow climb from Whitbourn Saddle via Snow White and 

Maori glaciers.

routes.name: The East Ridge.
routes.description: From the summit of Maori descend the shattered rock of the West Face to the col on the Main Divide. The East Ridge of Maiti-iti is a climb of about 100 metres, consisting of a lower section of loose rock and a more difficult and exposed upper section, before a short snow ridge leads to the summit, about l.5 hours from Maori. The col between Maori and Maiti-iti could probably be reached from the Dart Névé.

routes.name: The South Face.
routes.description: The steep snow face of Maiti-iti is reached by climbing straightforward snow slopes beneath the ice-cliffs of the Park Glacier.
routes.ascent: Barry Scott & Rob Petit, Dec 1974.

routes.name: From south branch South Temple
routes.description:
From the South Temple Hut follow the southernmost branch of the South Temple 
stream on the true right, climbing past a small gorge at G38, GR497 690, to 
reach the upper basin. Beginning near the final branch in the stream, ascend 
the slopes on loose rock in summer, to reach the summit.
routes.ascent: First ascent unknown

routes.name: West Face
routes.description:
From a camp in the Hunter Valley West Branch, underneath Upper Studholme 
Pass, climb the tussock slopes and rock to gain the summit.
routes.ascent: John Chivers, Caroline Cotton, Rob Mitchell, Euan Warburton, Laurie White , January 1962

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/fiordland/d.name: Mt Makere
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/fiordland/d.description: While the ridges are easy climbs, Mt Makere’s South Face has three outstanding rock routes and potential for more. Incorrectly marked on topomaps as Waitiri.

routes.name: South Ridge
routes.description: The South Ridge was first reached by a traverse from the summit of Waitiri.
routes.ascent: Bill Gordon, Ralph Miller, December 1955

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aoraki/main.name: Malaspina
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aoraki/main.description: A prominent gully north of Malaspina may provide a quick alternative to the route to the Grand Plateau over Clarke Saddle.  See Clarke Saddle and the "Via Clarke Saddle" Route of Mt Teichelmann/Rakirua.

routes.name: West Ridge
routes.description: Ascend a rock ridge onto a major bump in the ridge. Then across a sweeping snow saddle to a final buttress of four rope lengths which lead to the summit.
routes.ascent: David Elphick, M White, Feb 1957 (Lower section).

routes.name: East Rib
routes.description: From the Burnett Glacier ascend the rib that reaches the Divide just south of the summit.
routes.ascent: J B Waterhouse, Dec 1985

routes.name: Original Route
routes.description: Easily climbed from the Tasman Glacier.
routes.ascent: Franz & Julius Malcher, Feb 1914.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/main-divide.name: Malcolm Pk
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/main-divide.description: Southern Alps Ka Tiritiri O Te Moana

routes.name: North West Face
routes.description:
This climb was inspired by photographs taken by Ebenezer Teichelmann in 1911. Best
approached from Heim Plateau, via the col between Malcolm and Hidden Peaks that leads
down to the Malcolm Glacier. A more difficult approach exists via Rangitata Col and the col
west of Malcolm Peak, descending snow gullies and rock to the remains of Malcolm Glacier.
The 500-metre climb is on good rock slabs with a crack providing the crux.
routes.ascent: Guy McKinnon March 2006

routes.name: South West Ridge
routes.description:
From Rangitata Col continue along the Divide, eventually reaching the rocky buttresses of the
South West Ridge. The climbing is straightforward on good rock.
routes.ascent: Andy Anderson, Bruce Turner, Jack Hayes (descended), February 1934

routes.name: West Ridge
routes.description:
From Lambert Col via the upper Frances Glacier and Main Divide
To avoid the gut directly below Lambert Col, sidle south onto a snow shoulder then sidle northeast back to the Frances Glacier. At 2000m, a significant crevasse can be challenging to cross. Continue up to Malcolm Col then SE, where there are smaller crevasses to the Main Divide under pt 2283m. Follow the Divide along with some easy rockclimbing involved near pt 2276m. From a patch of gravel low on the SW ridge, climb diagonally across the western face towards the NW arete. An easy walk on the ridge completes the climb.
routes.ascent: Ebenezer Teichelmann, Peter Graham, Jack Clarke (from the Lord River), February 1911

routes.name: North Spur
routes.description: Ascend snowslopes under Hidden Peak to the col south of pt 2248m. There are various rock climbing possibilities on reasonably good greywacke up a headwall to reach the North arete. The easiest approach is to access the shallow gully at J35 329656 between two minor ribs and follow that up. Sometimes there are snow patches in this gully and sometimes it is bare rock. The north arete is then an easy scramble to the top

routes.name: North East Ridge
routes.description:
From Heim Plateau, cross to the head of the Malcolm Glacier. Traverse round to a small glacier
draining the North East Ridge. Climb the glacier and follow the ridge to the summit.
routes.ascent: H W (Sandy) Cormack, Lloyd Wilson, January 1933

routes.name: East Buttress
routes.description:
From Heim Plateau, traverse south-west to meet the foot of the East Buttress. Climb steep rock
and a snow arête to the summit.
routes.ascent: Stan Conway, Alan Barnes, Syd Brookes, September 1937

routes.name: South East Rib
routes.description:
This route is immediately south of the East Buttress and is reached via a traverse from McCoy
Col to the col linking the glacier basin at the head of the Lyell Glacier with Heim Plateau. At
the start of the route, bypass a 15-metre buttress via a steep gully on the left, and head diagonally
across to a well-defined rib which tops the buttress. Follow the rib on loose rock to the summit
ridge and eventually join the East Buttress route from Heim Plateau.
routes.ascent: Ambrose Banfield, Arthur Lees, Bruce Banfield, December 1939

routes.name: East Face
routes.description: From the Heim Plateau, climb a steep snow face to join the East Buttress just below the summit. Snowboard descents.
routes.ascent: Ryan Nicol, Yossi Jagger Nov 2015

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aoraki/fox-.name: Mt Mallory
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aoraki/fox-.description: Southern Alps Ka Tiritiri O Te Moana

routes.name: From the Franz Josef
routes.description: The snow ramp from the Franz Josef side, involves some rock near the summit.
routes.ascent: E Sealy, I Johnson, David Lewis, J T Holloway, Jan 1937.

routes.name: Standard Routes
routes.description: From Irvine Peak via snow or rock, or from Albert Peak and Betty Peak in the east.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aoraki/malt.name: Malte Brun
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aoraki/malt.description: The routes on the western side of Mt Malte Brun provide good rock climbing and can be gained either via the Turnbull Glacier, which joins the upper Bonney Glacier, or up the Malte Brun Glacier.

routes.name: North East Ridge
routes.description: Descend from Mt Hamilton to a narrow rubbly notch and climb up a steep slab for 150m, then on up the ridge, which rises in a series of short steps of good rock.
routes.ascent: Harry Ayres, Bruce Gillies, Feb 1951.

routes.name: North Face
routes.description: From the lower Bonney Glacier ascend the ribs and slabs of excellent rock between the North East and North Ridges. There is plenty of room for variations.
routes.ascent: A C Rattray, J C Stamers-Smith, Dec 1958.

routes.name: Multi Sport (North Face)
routes.description:
Up prominent rock rib to the right of the gully on the North face to the from the Bonney Glacier.

15 - 20 pitches 

2/3 of the route was on fantastic rock. The last 1/3 was quite chossy.

First accent was done with bivy gear and the team descended down the Bonney Rib.
routes.ascent: Asher March, Richie Jacomb FFA March 2019

routes.name: North Ridge
routes.description: This route usually commences from the Bonney Glacier just above the small icefall but there is wide scope for variations especially from below the icefall. The rock on the ridge is good and the climbing pleasantly interesting but nowhere difficult. An enjoyable climb for a sunny day.
routes.ascent: Peter Graham, Henrik Sillem, Mar 1906.

routes.name: North West Face
routes.description: Scene of Tom Fyfe’s remarkable 1894 solo climb. Fyfe’s route ascends to the left of a shallow couloir in the centre of the face. Other routes ascend to the right of the couloir while some variations keep closer to the North Ridge. Although the climbing is not very difficult, it is still quite sustained.
routes.ascent: Tom Fyfe, Mar 1894.

routes.name: Fyfe’s Couloir
routes.description: From the névé of the Bonney Glacier, ascend the snow and ice couloir to within l00m of the summit. This can make a quick descent route, but it is a natural funnel for rock fall and avalanches.
routes.ascent: F McMahon, A Simpson, R Yates, Dec 1964.

routes.name: Bonney Headwall
routes.description: From the Bonney Glacier climb compact rock that steepens progressively to a crux before a snowcovered ledge  Access the ledge toward either the left or the right. Continue up rock directly to the Cheval or follow the ledge which ramps to the right, arriving on the West Ridge about 60m west of the Cheval. Not recommended as a descent.
routes.ascent: Brendan Gaynor, Ewan Reid, John Zapp, John Menin, Dec 1971.

routes.name: West Ridge
routes.description: This route, or rather series of routes, starts from the head of the Malte Brun Glacier and joins the West Ridge proper well before the “Cheval”, a famous and spectacular narrow section of ridge. The easiest route begins by cutting left from the head of the Malte Brun Glacier up one of a series of couloirs onto a small snowfield and then up a short rock face onto the ridge. An enjoyable alternative, however, is to climb the beautiful rock rib from the col which separates the Malte Brun and Bonney Glaciers. The climbing on these routes is exposed, but not too difficult. On reaching the true West Ridge negotiate the Cheval and then up 200m to the summit. This route is used regularly for descents but be sure to remember where to turn off the West Ridge in order to reach the head of the Malte Brun Glacier.
routes.ascent: Laurence Earle, Freda Du Faur, Peter Graham, Jan 1910.

routes.name: Full West Ridge
routes.description:
From the Beetham Valley the best route is probably to cut across the toe of West Ridge and ascend above the old Malte Brun Hut site, regaining the ridge at a col at 2300m. Follow the ridge on generally good rock. The climb steepens and provides some difficulty before easing off where West Ridge is joined. Cross the Cheval and continue up 200m to the summit.
Laurence Earle, Freda Du Faur, Peter Graham, Jan 1910.
At least one of the pillars on the north side of the lower ridge has been climbed, and provides excellent climbing (crux 16).
routes.ascent: Max Dorflinger, Otto Von Allmen, Dec 1972.

routes.name: South Ridge
routes.description: From Malte Brun Pass head up the ridge, skirting the first pinnacles on the west side, and then up the crest of the ridge, which rises in two long steps. The rock is highly variable and in parts the ridge is quite exposed. Despite this most of the ridge is on snow and ice.
routes.ascent: Peter Graham, Claude Macdonald, Jim Murphy, Feb 1909

routes.name: Biophilia
routes.description:
An objectively 'safe' rock route with compact featured slabs. A great way to access the West Ridge and descend. Reached from the top of the Malte Brun Glacier either at the left hand edge (grade 16), or more easily up the right hand ramp (see white lines on photo). Rap stations (pitons and nuts) have been established at roughly 60m length on ascent. The route was first attempted up to pitch 4.5 in mountain boots in 2015, and retreat was due to lack of gear. The first complete ascent was done with rock shoes in optimal climbing conditions, switching to approach shoes at the apex of the West Ridge. BYO rap cord and expect to replace it completely.
Route photo taken from summit of Rumdoodle in February 2015 with slightly more snow on the route than on the first complete ascent.
Useful GPS waypoints, current in 2020 are:
The point to aim for when climbing the moraine wall (this will get you to the old Malte Brun hut site: 
Lat: -43.54864
Long: 170.28069
NZTM 1380331  5174664
Elevation: 1640m

Top of the access gully:
Lat: -43.55025
Long:170.28311
Elev: 1828m

Bivvy site (there are many others):
Lat: -43.55298
Long: 170.28782
Elev: 2036m
routes.ascent: Ruari MacFarlane, Gavin Lang 6th March 2020

routes.name: North West Ridge
routes.description: From Stewart Saddle snow slopes lead to the Main Divide ridge of the peak. The rock ridge can be climbed with a couple of gendarmes to turn on the Godley side, but it is easier to reach the Divide just west of the peak.
routes.ascent: JS Shanks, A Carty, HF Smith, LJ Dumbleton, 25th Dec 1934.

routes.name: Unnamed
routes.description: Climb to the plateau south-west of the peak by any number of routes from the Godley Glacier. From the plateau join the Main Divide or use the rock face to the south.
routes.ascent: T A Fletcher, Will Kennedy, A Sutton-Turner, Jack Lippe, Dec 1920

routes.name: South Rib
routes.description: From the Godley Glacier climb the rock and snow rib which leads onto the peak.
routes.ascent: Gary Ball, P Gill, W Hewson, D Henson, P Bennett, Mike Andrews, Dec 1972

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/nelson-lake.name: Manakau
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/nelson-lake.description: Highest peak on the Seaward Kaikoura Range, Manakau is a major climb with a large height gain. In summer it is barren, hot and dry, in winter a long snow climb during short daylight hours. In fine weather the views are magnificent. The first ascent is thought to be by James Ingram in 1874.

routes.name: Via Uwerau
routes.description: Continuing to Manakau from Uwerau is straightforward.

routes.name: East Face
routes.description: The East Face has been climbed in spring conditions, but this is steep and rugged terrain, guarded by a gorge and waterfalls in Stace Creek.

routes.name: Surveyor Spur Route
routes.description: Surveyor Spur is the spur between Mt Stace and the main range. Follow the Hapuku River north branch, now choked with shingle after the 2016 earthquake, until the river swings northeast below Stace Saddle. Further upstream, the old Barratts Hut and bivvy are buried under a large landslip, which has also destroyed an alternative route onto the spur. The summit is an 1850m height gain, so it’s best to camp higher if possible. Stace Saddle (1045m) is easily reached, then follow the spur. The first few hundred metres above the saddle has many tension cracks about 0.5m deep. Fine in daylight but easy to miss by head torch, and not good in wet conditions. There is a good campsite near some large boulders at about 1940m, and in winter and spring there will usually be snow hereabouts. Elsewhere the spur is waterless. Angle up easy slopes to an obvious dip in the main range. In summer it may be necessary to camp in the Stace Creek basin below this dip. Continue along the ridge crest, which steepens beyond a shallow saddle, and bypassing some gendarmes on the north side. Inexperienced parties may prefer a rope here. The traverse to Uwerau is generally straightforward and especially satisfying.

routes.name: Surveyor Spur alternative
routes.description: Access to an alternative route onto Surveyor Spur, starting from O31 659 850 / BT27 559 234, appears no longer possible after the 2016 earthquake. The route was as follows: At a large cairn before the first major tributary on the true right, look for a plastic road marker pole. Initially follow through fern, then move left onto a steep open slope with tussock and scrub. Keep left of all major slips. From a small grass terrace, climb through alpine shrubs, lightly cut. Occasional poles mark the route, however most are not visible from above, hence this route is difficult to follow as a descent, especially if snow covered in the alpine scrub section. Then follow a narrowing ridge. At about 1300m is a small open bivvy site (no water). The route meets the main Surveyor Spur just above the 1940m campsite.

routes.name: North Ridge
routes.description: A remote and very long route from the Waiau Toa Clarence valley. The lower part of the ridge – Fidget Spur – can be reached in two ways. One is from the end of the 4WD track at Stony Flat on the south bank of the Waiau Toa Clarence River (55 km from Kahutara Bridge on the Inland Kaikoura Road). The alternative is from the lower Waiau Toa Clarence, via George Saddle and Haycock Saddle and picking up an old overgrown pack route which sidles westwards and descends to Fidget Stream. Gain the ridge on the true left of Fidget Stream by any convenient side spur. Abseil into the crux, an 80m deep notch. Continue climbing on solid rock till a second 25m deep notch is reached, abseil into this, and then easier ground to the summit.
routes.ascent: Dave Barker, Roger Redmayne, Trevor Bissell, Bruce Anderson, February 1986

routes.name: Dubious Stream Route
routes.description: A very remote route. Dubious Stream can be reached from the lower Waiau Toa Clarence via George Saddle, Haycock Saddle to Fidget Stream and then via Spring Gully and Packers Stream, or else by the 4WD track on the south bank of the Waiau Toa Clarence River to Goose Flat (50 km from Kahutara Bridge on the Inland Kaikoura Road). A high scree basin north-west of Manakau can be reached via a main eastern tributary of Dubious Stream just upstream of Lacebark Stream.

routes.name: South West Ridge
routes.description: From Whataroa Saddle ascend snow and rock on the Main Divide, passing an overhang near the summit by using a gut nearby or turning to the north-west side. An alternative route from the saddle lies up the slopes on the western side, approaching the summit from the south-west.
routes.ascent: Otto Frind, Conrad Kain, Mar 1914

routes.name: West Face
routes.description: From the Whataroa. Interesting rock slabs and snow patches.
routes.ascent: Dave Bamford, John Nankervis, Grant Stotter, Richard Hancock, Feb 1977

routes.name: East Rib
routes.description: Gained from the Classen Glacier.
routes.ascent: Keith McNaughton, John Gamlen, Jan 1967

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aspiring/sn.name: Mt Maori
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aspiring/sn.description: First climbed on March 5, 1935, by Russell and Gordon Edwards, Ernie Smith, and Doug Knowles, Maori repulsed further advances for 25 years, until Les and Doug Brough, Lindsay Bruce, and Alex Gourlay finally succeeded from the Snow-White Glacier after a series of  attempts totalling 55 days spread over seven years.  The route of the original ascent from the Dart was not repeated until 1966.

routes.name: From the Whitbourn Saddle
routes.description:
From the Whitbourn Saddle via the Snow White and ‘Maori’ glaciers, reach 

the South West Ridge and follow it to the top.

routes.name: The East Ridge.
routes.description: From Cascade Saddle follow route 3.1 before veering left under the South Face of Wahine to reach Pakeha Col. The route on Maori zig-zags up a series of  rotten rock ledges on the Dart Face to regain the ridge above the main gendarme. Above this the rock improves somewhat but is still poor, with some delicate towers just below the summit. The climb would take about five hours from Cascade Saddle and one and a half hours from Pakeha Col.
routes.ascent: Russell & Gordon Edwards, Ernie Smith & Doug Knowles, March 1935.

routes.name: The South Face.
routes.description: Follow route towards Pakeha Col and the East Ridge then drop down to underneath the face. The route parallels the East Ridge through a rock band on mixed ground, and up steep snow slopes to the summit. This is a good mixed route and of better quality than the East Ridge.
routes.ascent: Allan Uren & Phil Penney, April 1987. First winter ascent: John Marcussen, James Broadbent, Don French and Nick Groves, Sept 1999.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aspiring/sn.name: Mt Maoriri
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aspiring/sn.description: Maoriri was first climbed in December 1937, by George Lockwood, Arch Wiren, and Jock Sim by traversing below the ridge from Edward, but there is no record of a direct ascent from the Dart.

routes.name: The East Face.
routes.description: The direct route is up snow slopes from Whitbourn Saddle.

routes.name: The South Ridge.
routes.description: From Edward a traverse along or below the ridge to Maoriri appears straightforward.

routes.name: From the Névé
routes.description: From the névé between Syme Ridge and Mt Dixon climb directly to the Col. The last 200m are steep. An easier route is via the East Face of  Lendenfeld Peak.
routes.ascent: Freda Du Faur, Peter Graham, C Milne, Apr 1912.

routes.name: From Pioneer Hut
routes.description: From Pioneer Hut a route around Haast Corner is usually viable early in the season but may require careful route finding through crevasses. If this option is cut off an alternative can be found under Lendenfeld Peak – continue from under Haast further up the Heemskirk Glacier. Beware of cornices on the col - scene of a few falls! The route is not difficult but can require some crevasse navigation.

routes.name: From the col
routes.description:
Canbe tackled by crossing the Foster glacier to reach the col between Mt 
Clarke and Mt Marchant, and from there along the Divide to the summit.
routes.ascent: Nick Banks and others 1970s

routes.name: From the Landsborough
routes.description:
Acessed from a camp above the Landsborough River.Gain height to reach the col 
between Mt Marchant  and Mt Clarke, and from the col climb the south ridge to 
the summit.
routes.ascent: Alan McNaught, Jim McNulty, Ray Slater, February 1951

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/fiordland/d.name: Marian Pk
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/fiordland/d.description: Although the ridges are straightforward, the North Face was something of a breakthrough for New Zealand climbing in 1973, due to the level of commitment and its unprotectable nature.

routes.name: West Ridge
routes.description: Starting from the summit of Barrier Peak the blocky ridge continues over to Marian: very exposed but easy travel.
routes.ascent: A D Jackson, 1934.

routes.name: East Ridge
routes.description:
A pleasant rock ridge from the Marian Sabre Col.
The route may require a short abseil on the descent but it can be down climbed.
routes.ascent: Mike Gill, Phil Houghton, Jan 1959.

routes.name: North East Rib
routes.description: At the head of the snow-field, four pitches up a clean rock rib to the summit ridge.
routes.ascent: Graham Clendon, Murray Judge, Nov 1972.

routes.name: Gong Show!
routes.description: Starting from the level section of central spur (the Sabre Marian gully central spur), traverse two sketchy pitches over to start of obvious buttress (pitons useful). Traversing to here avoids the hideously vegetated terrain below and takes you straight to the real climbing. Climb four pitches up buttress on good rock. Mixture of broken slabs and corners with cracks. Good gear. Rock gets better the higher you go (crux 18). Terrain then eases to scramble to summit. Originally accessed from Marian Peak.
routes.ascent: Mike Buchanan, Ivor Koo. Feb 2013

routes.name: Normal Route
routes.description: Short easy routes exist from the Sladden Névé up the northern rock and snow slopes of Mts Jean, Jeanette and Marie.
routes.ascent: Conrad Kain, M Sloman, Jan 1916.

routes.name: Birdland
routes.description:
Ascend the south spur by an excellent rock rib, gain height on snow then 
climb two challenging rock pitches. Easy snow fields lead to the summit tower 
and five zig zag pitches up snow and ice to the summit.
routes.ascent: Ross Cullen, Bill McLeod, November 1993

routes.name: North West Ridge
routes.description: Completed as part of a traverse along the Divide. The broken rocky ridge is time-consuming.
routes.ascent: Roger Chester, December 1930

routes.name: West Face
routes.description:
Follow the steep creek on the south side of Mt Carl until a gap in the spur on the right allows
access to rock ribs and the glacier draining the ridge between Mt Marion and Pt 1883 metres.
Continue up here alongside a rock wall until slabs below a prominent arête allow access to the
glacier and West Face of Mt Marion. Climb the glacier towards the rocky summit. The final
few metres involve some awkward rock climbing and lead to the ridge just south of the flat top.

routes.name: South East Ridge
routes.description: Completed as part of a traverse along the Divide. The broken rocky ridge is time-consuming.
routes.ascent: Roger Chester, December 1930

routes.name: North West Ridge
routes.description: A rocky climb on a steep, loose ridge from Mt Pope.

routes.name: South West Ridge
routes.description:
From the upper Wilberforce River climb scree, steep rock and tussock to a group of tarns at the
foot of the South West Ridge, and follow this to the summit.

routes.name: North East Ridge
routes.description: Climb the broken ridge from Mt Rosamond.
routes.ascent: George McElroy, Neville Barker, R Caldwell, March 1934

routes.name: From The East
routes.description: Reached either by a traverse under Mt Maoriri and Mt Edward from Whitbourn Saddle

routes.name: Direct
routes.description: direct from the Whitbourn River below the Whitbourn Glacier (refer to Troas).

routes.name: From the Hunter Valley
routes.description: TBA
routes.ascent: Peter Child and Stuart Ombler, January 1952

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/main-divide.name: Mt Martius
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/main-divide.description:
Mt Martius is named on older maps, such as the 1962 NZAC map, but not the latest metric series. It is
Pt 2031 metres, and has a big cairn on it.

routes.name: South Ridge
routes.description: The ridge is gained from Lauper Stream.
routes.ascent: A B Griffin, H Nelson, A A Treolar, May 1934

routes.name: Via Main Divide
routes.description:
Climb small spurs directly east of Whitcombe Pass (see Access from Whitcombe Pass, previous
page). The north ridge is straightforward, while the west ridge would provide a more interesting
rock climb.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aspiring/sn.name: Maruiwi
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aspiring/sn.description: Maruiwi was formerly known as Moriori. The first ascent was by Jim Dawson, Bob Craigie, Phil Cook, and Scott Gilkison on January 7, 1939, from the Snow-White Glacier.

routes.name: From Whitbourn Saddle
routes.description:
From Whitbourn Saddle and Snow White Glacier either climb up the 

glacier or a snow couloir on the north face to the North West Ridge then traverse the West Face and complete the ascent up the snow face to the south; or climb the west snow face to the rock ridge on the Divide and follow this to the summit.

routes.name: Via the Park Glacier.
routes.description: It appears possible to reach the extreme northern end of the Park Glacier by a steep snow face with an upper rock band, at the south-west end of the shelf of the hanging glacier beneath Maiti-iti and Maori. From the Park Glacier the summit could he reached by easy snow routes on either the North East or South Ridges.
routes.ascent: The snow face was climbed from the Dart Névé by Phil Penney and Simon Harris

routes.name: From Mettelille & Sladden Glaciers
routes.description: Routes may be found almost anywhere up either the North Face from the Metelille Glacier or the short South Face from the Sladden Glacier. Rock buttresses further down the South Face should give good rock climbing.
routes.ascent: Hugh Wright, J Robertson, Feb 1915.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aoraki/fran.name: Matenga Pk
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aoraki/fran.description: This is the highest peak on the Lindon Ridge which extends westward from the Minarets. Probably first climbed via its west ridge.

routes.name: Standard Route
routes.description: This is the highest peak on the Lindon Ridge which extends westward from the Minarets. Probably first climbed via its west ridge.
routes.ascent: Alex Graham, Miss Marsden, May, 1916.

routes.name: Cleavage
routes.description: The deep gully in the middle of the south face of Matenga. 2 pitches of moderate ice, followed by a pitch of easier ground to the ridge.
routes.ascent: Mike Peat, Tom Wilson October 2007

routes.name: East Slopes
routes.description:
The eastern snowslopes provide straightforward access to the final rock 
needle.
routes.ascent: Marjorie Edgar-Jones, Gladys Acton-Adams, Frank Alack, TomChristie, March 1935

routes.name: From the Morse River
routes.description:
Climb out of the head of the Morse River and follow the north ridge to the 
summit.
routes.ascent: Nina Dickerhof, James Thornton, January 2016

routes.name: Eastern Slopes
routes.description: The eastern snowslopes provide straightforward access.
routes.ascent: Marjorie Edgar-Jones, Gladys Acton-Adams, Frank Alack, Tom Christie. March 1935

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/ni/tongariro/m.name: Matihao (Cathedral Rocks)
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/ni/tongariro/m.description: Hardly looking like peaks at all from the Summit Plateau, Matihao can lay a solid claim to having the best ice routes on Ruapehu on its South Face.

routes.name: From Summit Plateau
routes.description: From the Summit Plateau the three outcrops of Matihao are easy climbs – the southern two being short, steep clambers.

routes.name: Accidental Pleasure
routes.description:
Start as for Lahar View, then head left.  After first step follow left hand chimney and corner until you reach as small ledge/pinnacle then follow left trending ice bulges unto upper slopes. After easy grade runout surmount last step and follow easy grade slopes to belay at the top.

We did it in three pitches. 

Possibly climbed before, but a great outing and worth a mention/ description.
routes.ascent: Adam Power, Dion Fabbro 2020

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/%C5%8Dhau-l.name: Mauka Atua
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/%C5%8Dhau-l.description: The highest point of the Ben Ohau Range was believed (incorrectly), to be still unclimbed as recently as 1968, when it was climbed from Whale Stream via a lengthy scramble across the ridge tops and western slopes. While a first ascent of Pt 2466m was made along the way, the first ascent of Mauka Atua seems likely to have been made by Norman Hardie in 1948. “I now see that I should have recorded in 1948–49 all that I did as an engineer at Pūkaki. At various stages I had working for me W McFarlane, A Cookson, E Hillary, and others who were not really climbers. With MOW vehicles and able to watch the weather, I traversed most of the Ben Ohau Range from Dun Fiunary to Dark Peak in 1948.” – Norman Hardie, 1992

routes.name: South Ridge
routes.description: From either Twin Stream or Back Bush Stream, follow the south ridge of Kai Tarau and either traverse the summit or, if there is good snow cover, sidle below through bluffs at about 2360m altitude to the col south of Mauka Atua. Finish with an easy scramble to the top.
routes.ascent: Norman Hardie, 1948

routes.name: East Face
routes.description: Follow Back Bush Stream until at 1450m altitude. The east face appears broken and loose but excellent progress can be made up a streambed at BY15 615 386 to gain the north ridge. From here, the summit of Mauka Atua is gained by a 1km long ribbon of narrow ridge.
routes.ascent: Ross Cullen, March 1989

routes.name: North Ridge
routes.description: Ascend the bush-clad spur north of the obvious stream opposite Kennedy Hut, then through snow tussock basins to join the Ben Ohau range crest just north of Pt 2515m. Then head south along a narrow and airy ridge to the summit.
routes.ascent: Hugh Nicholson, January 1996

routes.name: From Mueller Glacier
routes.description: Direct from the Mueller Glacier to the Ngakanohi Glacier and continue up the East Rib to the summit. Glacial retreat since the first ascent has made the lower part of this climb loose, unpleasant and quite dangerous.
routes.ascent: Otto Frind, Konrad Kain, Peter Graham, February 1914

routes.name: Via Frind Glacier
routes.description: From the Frind Glacier, use the rocks or avalanche cones near the Ngaroimata Falls, gain the glacier and traverse diagonally up the Ngakanohi Glacier to the East Rib which is followed direct to the summit up rotten rock (covered by snow early in the season).
routes.ascent: Otto Frind, Konrad Kain, Peter Graham, February 1914

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aspiring/ba.name: McBride Pks
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aspiring/ba.description: The peaks can be reached from Fohn Saddle via Brenda Peak and the top or the middle neve, or the Merkl Glacier. The summit ridge can be traversed for most of its length.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/main-divide.name: McClure Pk
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/main-divide.description: McClure Peak is at the junction of the Two Thumb Range and the Main Divide and stands out as a perfect snow pyramid when looking up the Havelock Valley from the vicinity of Black Mountain Hut. McClure Peak was first climbed from Terra Nova Pass by Jack Lippe and Will Kennedy, February 1925.

routes.name: South Ridge
routes.description:
From Terra Nova Pass, follow the ridge to Saint Winifred Col. From here climb snow and rock,
bypassing a large rock buttresses on the eastern side.
routes.ascent: William A Kennedy, Jack Lippe, February 1925

routes.name: West Face
routes.description:
From the upper Godley Glacier head up a tributary glacier to the Main Divide west of the peak. The West Face is fairly broad with relatively easy rock and scree slopes. This tributary glacier is likely to be cut off by crevasses at times, especially later in the season. 
A variation on this route has been used, approaching from Stewart Pass along the Main Divide snows of Malthus and Dennistoun.
A second variation of this route is to approach from Dummy Col up the shingle bed of Eric Stream from the Havelock Valley. From Dummy Col, continue to Hidden Col, then cross snowslopes to a rib at about 2120m giving access to the same West Face.
routes.ascent: Jack Pattle, Allan Cookson, Charles (Gordon) Buchanan, Neville Barker, March 1937

routes.name: North Ridge
routes.description:
From Hidden Col climb the glacier north of McClure Peak. At its head, follow a steepening
couloir almost directly to the summit, or move on to shattered rock either side of the couloir.
routes.ascent: Eric de Lacey, Russell Pearce, G W Watson, February 1967

routes.name: From Terra Nova Pass
routes.description: From Terra Nova Pass climb the snow and rock south ridge, avoiding large rock buttresses on the eastern side, regaining the ridge about 200m from the summit. This is more difficult than it looks.
routes.ascent: Will Kennedy, Jack Lippe, Feb 1925

routes.name: Unnamed
routes.description: Climb directly from the head of the Godley using a tributary glacier to access the Main Divide west of the summit.
routes.ascent: First Ascent Unknown

routes.name: North Slopes
routes.description:
Readily accessible  from near the head of Jacks Creek. Sidle past Lantern 
Peak to reach the extensive snowfields north of the peak and the easy climb 
to the summit.
routes.ascent: First ascent unknown

routes.name: South Face
routes.description:
Mt McCullaugh is encircled by a glacier and is readily climbable by choosing 
a route from Murdock Creek and sidling west toward the head of McCullaugh 
Stream. Easy angled snowslopes lead northward to the summit.
routes.ascent: Jack Aitken, Jack Gillespie, Eric Miller, Alma Mitchell, M.Sutherland, January 1944

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aoraki-tai-.name: McFetrick Pk
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aoraki-tai-.description: Probably named after Alex and Hughie McFetterich, who farmed Tartare Flat. Sometimes traversed en route to or from the head of the Callery River. Frank Pearson, Alan Gill, and Gordon Howitt used this route to exit the Callery via the Gunn River and Price Range at Easter 1964.

routes.name: North West Ridge
routes.description:
From about the 1300-metre contour in the upper Gunn River, head north-west up moraine,
then scree and snow slopes, to the crest of the range. Easy travel along the range leads to the
summit.
To continue to the Callery, follow the range south over normally easy schrunds to Tartare
Saddle. A steep spur at I35 912509 / BX16 812 893 can be used to descend to the valley, where the
Callery River is normally easily crossed below the lake. Traversing around the lake is really only
practical on the true left.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/nelson-lake.name: Mt McKay
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/nelson-lake.description: St Arnaud Range

routes.name: North East Ridge Grade 2
routes.description: Via Rainbow River. Climb a broad, scrubby ridge from the junction of the north and south branches of the Rainbow, then sidle along a shelf (great campsite) and diagonally up narrow exposed platforms to a col north of the peak. Follow the range to the summit.  Beware of avalanches on all slopes.

routes.name: West Face / North Ridge
routes.description: Without crossing the swingbridge, follow the old track on the true left. From a large boulder at the southern end of the large clearing east-southeast of Mt Franklin, climb through forest to the bushline. Sidle upwards, crossing into a basin with a large tarn. Climb scree towards a col north-east of Mackay (map ref. M30/878040), and along the ridge.

routes.name: South Ridge Grade 2+
routes.description: A steep ridge rising from the northern pass (see route 6.06) can be bypassed via gullies falling to the source tarn of the East Sabine. Climb a large couloir at the head of the tarn, up a rock step and onto Peak 2180m. Gendarmes on the narrow main ridge to the summit can be sidled or climbed over.

routes.name: East Ridge
routes.description:
From the ridge connecting to Black Tower (route 3.32), an easy snowslope 
leads to the summit of McKerrow, the third highest peak in the region covered 
by this guidebook.
routes.ascent: Descended and ascended by Peter Beveridge, John Harrison, Wally Romanes and BrianWilliams, December 1955

routes.name: Orinoco Flow
routes.description:
Starting at the snow cone in the centre of the face under Mt McKerrow, climb 
directly to exit onto the upper snow field in line with the rock leading to 
the summit. There is a short steep section at first then follow up short 
bulges and ramps until reaching snowfields beneath the rockrib. Follow up 
snow on left of rock rib to the summit. 500 metres of ice on the lower shelf, 
and 500 m of snow slopes.
routes.ascent: Bill McLeod, June 1993

routes.name: South East Face
routes.description:
A route from the Richardson Glacier to the upper section of the west ridge 
avoids the schrunds above Mockery Col.
routes.ascent: D Laurie, Lindsay Wood 1968

routes.name: South Ridge
routes.description:
From anywhere on the Arthur Glacier there is only one peak. It dominates the 
valley completely, its long arms thrown around the head and along one side. 
Its snows feed and form the mile-long glacier. Spurs running off the great 
western ridge are truncated in huge bluffs. Cornices are palely blue, and the 
summit shimmers four thousand feet above. It has all the majesty of Hopkins 
combined with a lustrous beauty of its own. Bill Packard remarked wistfully 
that McKerrow was a peak worth wooing, and I knew then that we were committed 
to the climb. Steve Brockett, New Zealand Alpine Journal 1947.

 From Mockery Col stay close to the ridge until the snowslopes are gained and 
proceed up the snowfield to the summit. Schrunds en route are turned on both 
west and east sides.
routes.ascent: Steve Brockett, Bill Packard January 1947

routes.name: North West Ridge
routes.description:
Begin at the Landsborough River near Bubble Creek and climb the tussock 
slopes, bypassing a bluffy section on the north side to reach the Beith 
Glacier. Ascend the rapidly narrowing glacier and sidle up the north-facing 
slope to the summit. A long climb, which requires over 1700m of height gain.
routes.ascent: Conrad Kain, Samuel Turner, March 1914

routes.name: Fortune Favours the Bold
routes.description: 1100m line to the left of Orinoco Flow, simul-soloed.
routes.ascent: James Edwards, Steven Fortune, Paul Warnock, August 2005

routes.name: From Neish Plateau
routes.description: Traverse from Cumine or climb snow slopes from the Neish Plateau.
routes.ascent: Johannes Anderson, A Sutton-Turner, Jack Lippe, Will Kennedy, Dec 1920

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/otago/elcho.name: McNulty Pk
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/otago/elcho.description: The pivot of the North Huxley, South Elcho and Hopkins valleys.

routes.name: North Face
routes.description:
From the head of the South Elcho climb across the face on good quality rock 
to reach the summit ridge.
routes.ascent: Dave McNulty, Ray Slater, April 1969

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/fiordland/d.name: Mt McPherson
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/fiordland/d.description:
Often climbed as part of a traverse from Homer Saddle to Gertrude Saddle.
McPherson Cirque, below, has good winter routes.
The east facing cliffs to the left of Macpherson Cirque which finish below Talbot’s Ladder have a number of long gullies which form up occasionally to give quality winter climbing. They also have the advantage of quick easy access and a safe descent down Talbot’s Ladder to Homer Saddle.
Macpherson was named ‘Snowball’ by Grave and Talbot on the original ascent. On a fine day the summit provides panoramic 360 degree views of the mountains of Fiordland.

routes.name: Talbot’s Ladder
routes.description:
From Homer Saddle there is an easy route to Macpherson up the ridge, over a 
rock step known as Talbot's Ladder.
The rock step is not exactly a garden path, many parties have opted for a 
rope over this section.
In Winter, the Ladder is a fine excursion for a short day, with a grade of II 
2.
The descent of the ridge in Winter may well require an abseil or two. Note 
that the metal stakes on the ridge don't always follow the most natural 
descent line, nor are they always easy to locate.
routes.ascent: William Grave, Arthur Talbot, Jan 1910.

routes.name: Gulliver (North) Face
routes.description: Four pitches. Descend from the East Ridge to a snowfield on the north side and climb a rib to the summit.
routes.ascent: Geoff Gabites, Mark Gabites, 1980.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/nelson-lake.name: Mt McRae  and Pk 1915m
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/nelson-lake.description: Above Rainbow Skifield

routes.name: St Arnaud Range
routes.description: From the skifield head south-east up easy slopes to Mt McRae. Continue south to a saddle overlooking the Arnst basin and east towards Pk 1915m. Beyond here, the range is rugged and it is necessary to descend and sidle below bluffs, then regain the ridge in the vicinity of Pk 1880m.  The range south of here is easy ridge travel, and can also be reached easily via a track up the true left of St Ronans Stream (no longer maintained but easily followed, through open forest into delightful tussock basins). Some superb campsites near tarns.

routes.name: Lake Rotoiti Route
routes.description: Ascend the scree just north of the Lake Head Hut jetty and then the obvious gut, topping out on the range above Rainbow Skifield. Head south over easy ground.

routes.name: From the West
routes.description: An easy walk on gravel, either up the north-west ridge or from the south-west.

routes.name: North Ridge
routes.description: A straightforward climb from a break in the scrub about 600 metres west of Washbourne Hut.
routes.ascent: George Roberts, Charlie Douglas, 1880

routes.name: From the Tasman Glacier
routes.description: Using the access routes onto Mt Coronet, either cross the basin underneath Mt Coronet up onto the Main Divide or use the Main Divide from Mt Coronet itself and ascend to Mt Meeson.
routes.ascent: Hugh Chambers, Conrad Kain, Prof. Robinson, J Robertson, Hugh Wright, Feb 1915.

routes.name: West Rib
routes.description: From the glacier to the left of the rib, traverse into a narrow couloir breaching the length of the lower rib. Ascend the couloir to a snowslope and then up the final rock arête on good rock
routes.ascent: Dave Bamford, Peter Fullerton, George Kendall, John Nankervis, Jan 1978.

routes.name: From Lake Castalia Cirque
routes.description: Climb out of the Lake Castalia Cirque, normally via Leda Peak route, and traverse upper snow slopes.
routes.ascent: C Bentham, E Miller & S Turner, Jan 1929.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aoraki/main.name: Mt Meteor
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aoraki/main.description: The southern Divide ridge is steepish and rotten.

routes.name: Northern Approach
routes.description: The ridge from Jervois traverses a small peak and descends a short steep section before easy scrambling leads to the summit.
routes.ascent: Katie Gardiner, Jack Pope, Mar 1929.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/fiordland/d.name: Mighty Dur
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/fiordland/d.description: The Mighty Dur is the knob of hard red rock at the base of Taiaroa’s North Ridge.

routes.name: Yea, Nah, Dur!
routes.description:
P1 (14) 40m Up and right on the slab will take you to the beginning of the 
left leaning crack system
P2 (23) 35m Get onto the orange rock and follow 'the line' to a hanging belay 
below the first overlap
P3 (24) 25m Pull the lip then power up to another hanging belay on the left 
hand side of the 2nd overlap
P4 (20) 15m Takes you to a hanging belay before the grey rock
P5 (20) 40m Pull up, over and into a juggy vegetated groove that will lead 
you to the summit
One rap off the south side will get you to the col below Taiaroa.
routes.ascent: Zac Orme, Troy Mattingley Feb 2015

routes.name: Left Arete
routes.description: Seven superb pitches with everything you could wish for and more including: a tussock bollard belay; beautiful slabs; knife edge aretes; wild exposure; and a committing run out to finish. Descend by scrambling down the South side with one abseil to reach slabs to the east.
routes.ascent: James Spiers, Richard Thomson, Dave Vass, 6 February 2013

routes.name: Dur-rich-t
routes.description: The right arete of the Dur. Sensational climbing on immaculate rock.
routes.ascent: Rich Thomson, Rich Turner, 8 February 2016

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/fiordland/d.name: Mihj Pk
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/fiordland/d.description: Mihj Peak is shown incorrectly on topomaps as Pt 1644 metres, further south on the ridge.

routes.name: South Ridge
routes.description: From Moraine Creek climb slabs below the peak, angling left across the narrowing shelf to gain the ridge just north of Darran Pass. The first ascent party descended the West Ridge and traversed back to the foot of the South Ridge.
routes.ascent: Malcolm Imlay, Gerry Hall-Jones, April 1955

routes.name: East Face
routes.description: Eight pitches. Up tussock and slabs to the centre of the face, then climb direct to the summit.
routes.ascent: Murray Judge, Bronwyn Tilly, Judy Terpstra, Feb 1975.

routes.name: South West Face
routes.description: Cross over Darran Pass to gain this small face.
routes.ascent: Murray Jones, Vicki Thompson, 1974.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/fiordland/d.name: Mills Pk
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/fiordland/d.description: Bowen Valley

routes.name: South Ridge:
routes.description:
Posted by stanley on Fri, 2014-01-17 15:19 


Full account on my website www.mulvanyadventures.blogspot.com
routes.ascent: First ascent on 22-24 November 2013 by Paula Macfarlane, Reece McKenzie and Stanley Mulvany (SSNZAC)

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/fiordland/d.name: Mt Milne
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/fiordland/d.description: Inconspicuous on its western aspects, Mt Milneʻs mighty south face and the Cleft it rises out of are one of the great features of the central Darrans. Milne is incorrectly marked on topomaps as Mt Tarewai.

routes.name: Original Route
routes.description:
Climb the slabs of the northern side then follow a right-tending ledge system as it move into the centre of the face, avoiding the steep north-west aspects. 
This route is used as the common descent off Milne.
routes.ascent: Frank Milne, Samuel Turner, March 1921

routes.name: East Ridge
routes.description: Nine pitches to the summit on good rock.
routes.ascent: Dave Bamford, Kevin Helm, Feb 1980.

routes.name: South Ridge
routes.description: An easy scramble from Eric Stream.
routes.ascent: Edgar Williams, April 1930

routes.name: North Ridge
routes.description: From the col between Sword and Milne Peaks climb easy rock to the summit.
routes.ascent: John Pascoe, Bernie McGlynn, March 1950

routes.name: South East Ridge
routes.description:
From the Havelock River climb through grassy bluffs, following snow gullies where possible.
Eventually a snowfield is reached that leads to the South East Ridge. Follow the ridge, which is
slabby and loose near the summit.
routes.ascent: John Pascoe, Bernie McGlynn (descended), March 1950

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aoraki/main.name: Minarets
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aoraki/main.description: The Minarets are two peaks, west (3031m) and east (3040m).

routes.name: Original (Standard) Route
routes.description: A short snow climb from the plateau between Mt De La Beche and the Minarets. The plateau is reached by the West Ridge of De La Beche, De La Beche Ridge, or the West Face of the Minarets. The technical grade is from the plateau.
routes.ascent: Tom Fyfe, Malcolm Ross, February 1897

routes.name: Ranfurly Glacier
routes.description: From the Tasman Glacier there are a number of variations ascending the glacier. This route is highly dependent on favourable crevasse conditions.
routes.ascent: Freda Du Faur, Laurence Earle, Peter Graham, B Spencer, January 1910

routes.name: North East Ridge
routes.description: A long climb, usually approached along the Main Divide via Mt Coronet, Mt Meeson, Mt Vic and Mt Gold Smith. The ridge crest can be followed except for one or two places where a traverse on the west is necessary.
routes.ascent: Harry Ayres, Mick Bowie, F F Simmons, January 1938

routes.name: North West Face
routes.description: From the Geikie Snowfield, traverse around onto one of the feeder arms of the Spencer Glacier and ascend the prominent rock face onto the West Minaret via a series of interconnecting snow ramps that start at the centre of the face (400m of mixed climbing). The ramps steepen towards the top and finish three to four easy rope lengths west of the summit.
routes.ascent: Dave Bamford, Jim Strang, March 1979

routes.name: West Face
routes.description: From north of Graham Saddle ascend the prominent snowslopes to the saddle between De La Beche and the Minarets. There can be large schrunds at any time of year on this face, which involves sustained 40-degree snow slopes. The rock spurs nearer De la Beche have also been used. It's also possible to traverse the steep slopes under De La Beche and above the Rudolph Glacier, arriving high on the De La Beche Ridge.
routes.ascent: Hugh Chambers, Jack Clarke, February 1912 (descended)

routes.name: North West Ridge.
routes.description: Accessible from Lake Unknown or Park Pass and the Park Glacier or Theatre Flat.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/nelson-lake.name: Mt Misery
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/nelson-lake.description: Mahanga Ra

routes.name: Standard Route
routes.description: From the head of Lake Rotoroa a track climbs a steepening face on to a spur. At the bushline climb onto the Mahanga Range and follow it up to Mt Misery. The hut below (4 bunks, basic) can be difficult to locate in fog.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/fiordland/d.name: Mitis Pk
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/fiordland/d.description: tba

routes.name: Original Route
routes.description: Climb en route to the West Ridge of Mt Grave.
routes.ascent: Jack Ede, Leo Faigan, Roland Rodda, Paul Powell, Dec 1946.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/nelson-lake.name: Mitre Pk
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/nelson-lake.description: A prominent couloir reaching to a small col between the two summit pyramids gives the peak the appearance of a bishop’s mitre.

routes.name: North East Couloir
routes.description:
Via HODDER RV. From the Staircase Stream junction continue up the Hodder, and climb the prominent couloir to a narrow col at the top. Beyond here, some parties may require a rope. A short steep descent and then a short traverse leads to a final steep climb to the very small summit.
(via North ridge)
routes.ascent: Messrs Alexander, Fowler, Neville, Moore, Jan. 1895.

routes.name: South East Ridge
routes.description: Via HODDER RV. This impressive rock ridge can be gained from near Muzzle Saddle, or else via a snow couloir. Good scrambling on steep rock.
routes.ascent: John Nankervis, Ross Gooder, Bob Gunn, Jan. 1969.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/darrans/lla.name: Mitre Pk
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/darrans/lla.description: The popularity of Mitre Peak as a tourist icon, and the increasing accessibility of kayaks in the sound, has led to more and more ascents in recent years. Kayaking across to the base in the early mornings makes Mitre Peak a unique climbing experience found nowhere else in New Zealand. Still well worth the adventure, although recent parties have complained of seeing increasing rubbish and human waste.

routes.name: Traverse of Three Peaks
routes.description: From west to east.
routes.ascent: Ted Coates, John Howard, 1973.

routes.name: East Ridge
routes.description: From Deepwater Basin either take a water taxi or kayak out into the Fiord, following the edge of the shore till Sinbad Gully is reached. From the beach at Sinbad Gully head up the broad ridge over recent tree fall (2014) until a faint trail through the bush is reached along with the crest of the ridge. Traverse over the Footstool and descend to a saddle, which provides the only water (puddles) and a couple of camp spots on route. Then follow the ridge as it climbs to the high peak.
routes.ascent: J Dennistoun, 1910.

routes.name: North Face
routes.description: Two American climbers began at sea level from a buttress just left of a large landslide scar, arriving at the High Peak after four days and 25cm of rain!
routes.ascent: J Evans, J Foot, Mar 1965.

routes.name: West Ridge
routes.description: Follow the ridge from Anita Bay to the West Peak
routes.ascent: TW Preston and Party, Jan 1926.

routes.name: East Ridge
routes.description: Continue from the High Peak via the East Ridge.
routes.ascent: Ron Chapman, Colin Fearon, Dec 1961.

routes.name: South West Face
routes.description:
About 5 pitches (200m) up good rock. Crux was about grade 14 on about the 4th 
pitch. Remaining 300m was easy scrambling.
routes.ascent: Mike Berry, Brian Renwick. About 1977

routes.name: South East Ridge
routes.description: Climbed via Panorama, Bruce Murray, and Upton. Beyond Panorama and its snow plateau, the ridge had a mix of rock pinnacles and snow arêtes, while a tower before Upton Peak, like the peak itself, was turned on the north-east side. A shoulder of snow then led on to a narrow section of fine black crumbly rock that several early accounts disliked, followed by a step in the ridge that was passed on snow out to the left. Above this, a snow plateau with crevasses led them to the summit.
routes.ascent: A J Scott, Alf Brustad, Russell Fraser, January 1933

routes.name: From the West
routes.description:
From the Butler River South Branch,
access the upper Gino Watkins Glacier.
This may be difficult. Climb snow slopes
to the snow saddle between Mt Moffat
and Mt Livingstone and continue to the
summit
routes.ascent: Laurie Osborne, Bruce Waterhouse, John Harrison, B H (Snow) Williams, Jan 1954

routes.name: South West Ridge
routes.description:
The first ascent party camped on the
Nansen névé and crossed the west ridge
of Cassino to access the Gino Watkins
Glacier. The descent into the Gino
Watkins was particularly steep. From theGino Watkins Glacier climb the west face of Pt 2543 metres to access the Main Divide southwest
of Mt Moffat. The summit ridge was largely sidled on the left, returning to the Divide
just below the top for a final arête. Reported as scrambling, with the odd pitch along the Main
Divide.
routes.ascent: John Nankervis, Phil Castle, Grant Stotter, Pat Thorn, Dec 1978

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/fiordland/w.name: Mt Moir
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/fiordland/w.description: Mt Moir contains a wealth of classic rock routes on amazing diorite.

routes.name: Original Route
routes.description: From the snowfield below the North Face of Belle.
routes.ascent: Bill Gordon, Lloyd Warburton, Duncan Wilson, Oct 1953.

routes.name: North Ridge
routes.description: A stunning ridge-climb on large blocks of good rock. The steep step onto Moir’s Mate may require a rope and is often abseiled on the descent.
routes.ascent: Bill Gordon, Ralph Miller, Oct 1956.

routes.name: West Ridge
routes.description: A 500m ridge of good rock.
routes.ascent: Godfrey Reider, Ron Webster, Dick Wood, March 1959.

routes.name: South Face
routes.description:
For access to the South Face descend round the foot of the West Ridge. 
Five pitches. The route follows the central rib on medium-angled clean rock.
routes.ascent: Don Bogie, Geoff Gabites, 1978.

routes.name: South Ridge
routes.description:
For access,  descend round the foot of the West Ridge.
16 pitches. Two or three initial step pitches to gain the ridge then excellent rock to the summit.
routes.ascent: Richard Price, Conway Powell, 1976.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/fiordland/w.name: Moir's Mate
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/fiordland/w.description: The routes on Moir’s Mate are accessible as day climbs from Homer Hut.

routes.name: West Ridge. Grade
routes.description: From the North or West Hunter climb to the col between Mt Head and Moira Peak via the South East Ridge and the Grant Glacier (refer to West Ridge of Head Pk). Then follow the ridge to the summit.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/nelson-lake.name: Moki
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/nelson-lake.description: Southern end of Spenser Mts

routes.name: North Face
routes.description: From the shelf in SE ridge of Enid Pk, sidle easy slopes onto the peak. Alternatively, climb up the stream from Glacier Gully, bypassing small waterfalls on the true right.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aspiring/hu.name: Momus
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aspiring/hu.description: A traverse between Momus and Somnus is possible, generally along the long broken ridge.

routes.name: South East Face
routes.description:
From the Routeburn Track follow the track to Sugarloaf Pass. Above the bushline sidle left on snow grass ledges into the head of a small basin. Climb steepish gully (begins E40 341 019) gaining access to the basin above Bridal Veil Falls. From here follow snowfields to the couloir, which gives access to the summit.

From the Routeburn Track follow the true left of Bridal Veil Creek to bush edge. Follow the left branch to the head of the valley gaining tussock ledges above bluffs at about 1,400m, giving access to the basin above Bridal Veil Falls. This route is a good descent route, dropping into the eastern side at times.

routes.name: Unnamed
routes.description: From the Murchison riverbed head up grass and scree slopes to a basin north east of the peak, then onto the summit.
routes.ascent: Peter Graham, A Humphries, R B Seager, Mar 1918

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aspiring/ma.name: Moncrieff Pk
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aspiring/ma.description: The first ascent of Moncrieff (originally named Mercer) was made on January 4, 1959, by Garth Matterson, Don Mee and Dove Tarrant, from Moncrieff Col.

routes.name: The South Face.
routes.description:
Follow the Moncrieff Col route from Aspiring Flat to reach the snowfield below the col. Traverse north to reach the rib separating the Kitchener and Lucas Glaciers. This rib leads to a steep snowfield below the South Face, which is then climbed by a direct line to the summit. The rock is unpleasantly loose but otherwise not unduly difficult.

This is a very long climb from Aspiring Flat, probably requiring eight to ten hours to the summit, but the reward is a magnificent view. There is a bivvy rock on the Moncrieff Col route. This bivvy is big enough for three people to stay dry in even in the most atrocious conditions.
routes.ascent: Martyn Potter, Maurice Conway & Wayne McIlwraith, Jan 1970.

routes.name: From Moncrieff Col.
routes.description: Moncrieff can be climbed in a few minutes by easy slabs north east of Moncrieff Col.

routes.name: Via Scissors
routes.description: From the top of Scissors traverse to Hardies Gut and then continue up to Mt Montgomery.
routes.ascent: Otto Frind, Conrad Kain, February 1914

routes.name: Divide Ridge
routes.description:
Montgomery is an easy scramble along the ridge from either Scissors or Fyfe 
Pass.
routes.ascent: Tom Fyfe, George Graham, February 1894

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aoraki/main.name: Moonlight Pk
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aoraki/main.description: An easy ascent from Graham Saddle.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aspiring/ha.name: Moonraker
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aspiring/ha.description: The name is more inspiring than the peak, which was first climbed by Peter Brook, Colin Todd and Kemp Fowler on January 11, 1949.

routes.name: North West Ridge
routes.description: Traverse the Iso and Dipso Glaciers to the west ridge of Stargazer, which is crossed immediately below two prominent rock steps. The North Face of this ridge is descended by a series of snow gullies and the ridge then followed down about 400m on slopes of snow tussock, until a narrow shelf of snow tussock leads around into the cirque below the North West Face of Stargazer. As the ledge is followed north it becomes broad and sloping and an unpleasant slabby gut has to be crossed before the cirque is reached. From the cirque a snow spur leads out to a broad, gently sloping bench that runs below Spike and continues to the North West ridge of Moonraker. The North West Ridge consists of a short snow climb and 20m of easy rock. The peak is a long way from Colin Todd Hut and requires a bivvy, perhaps on the north side of the West Ridge of Stargazer.

routes.name: North West Ridge
routes.description: Traverse from Corner Post.
routes.ascent: H. T. Barcham, A. Cunningham, B. D. Mathews, G. J. McCallum, January 1951

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aoraki/frit.name: Moonshine Buttress
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aoraki/frit.description:
From the Explorer Glacier.
Upper Fritz Range. Not a named peak. NW of Conway and SW of Barnicoat

routes.name: Poor Visibility
routes.description:
On the left of the Moonshine Buttress is a nice
six pitch line of ice with a wee mixed section.
It follows the upper right arm of a prominent
‘X’ on the left side of the buttress. The first
ascentionists descended using V-threads.
routes.ascent: Michael Madden, Matt Quirke, Aug 2007

routes.name: Visually Impaired
routes.description:
Climb a thin ribbon of ice immediately right of
Moonshine Buttress. The crux on the first ascent
was a short, narrow chimney, followed by a few
metres of overhanging ice. Another full pitch
high on the route was very thin, with near to no
protection. The amount of reliable protection
may vary with ice conditions. Descending the
route was difficult and serious due to lack of
anchors. In similar conditions, it may be better to
abseil down the north ridge of Conway to the col,
and then down an easy snow gully.
routes.ascent: Michael Madden, Matt Quirke, Aug 2007

routes.name: Moonshine Buttress
routes.description: Climb the south-west rib from the névé for about nine rope lengths on good rock. Sustained grade 14/15 climbing with a crux of 17. The route weaves its way up the pinkest rock to the right of the broad flat buttress. Although descending into the Franz is possible it is not recommended. Abseil the route, using a range of fixed gear. A superb route – put this one on the list.
routes.ascent: Greg & Dean Landreth, Apr 1984.

routes.name: The Silver Fox
routes.description: A couloir to the left of the peak contains one steep pitch (65-70o). Arriving on the ridge west of the peak, traverse the summit and descend to Frenchay Col.
routes.ascent: Stu Gray, Brian Williamson, Jan 1988.

routes.name: Right Couloir
routes.description: Ascend a couloir to the right of Conway onto the Main Divide and traverse to the summit.
routes.ascent: R Bates, E McMahon, Nov 1976.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/westland/jo.name: Mt Moreton
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/westland/jo.description: The Moretons were itinerent artists who spent over a month at Duncans Hut in the Rakaia? in 1914.

routes.name: South Ridge
routes.description:
From south end of Lake Minchin, make your way (SE) about 100m-200m through 
the beech trees to the big scree that comes down from the open tops south of 
point 1471. Ascend scree to the tops and then head north along Snow Cup 
Range, over points 1564 and 1714 and then finally onto Mt Morrison at 1720m.  
Daryll Thomson, March 2017

routes.name: North East Spur

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/canterbury-.name: Mueller Pk
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/canterbury-.description: An iron trig was placed on Mueller Peak by George Roberts and Dan Strachan in about 1880.

routes.name: From Camp Saddle
routes.description:
From Camp Saddle follow moderate snow gullies to the top.
Camp Saddle named by JG Roberts, 1880s.

routes.name: From Gibson Stream
routes.description:
From Gibson Stream, climb through scree and steep tussock east of the bluffs and waterfall
draining the basin below Mt Treadwell. From this basin several options exist to the summit.

routes.name: North Ridge
routes.description: A straightforward climb from Mungo Pass.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/arthurs-pas.name: Mt Murchison
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/arthurs-pas.description:
Mt Murchison was first climbed by Charles Ward and Arthur Talbot in 1913 from the Waimakariri
River, via the White Glacier and North Ridge.

routes.name: White Glacier Route
routes.description: The usual route follows the glacier (up the true left of the icefall on an ice ramp) almost to Kahutea Col. Stay close beneath the North Ridge, to avoid the crevasse areas and then ascend the last couloir which joins the ridge near the summit. (Note : Wet snow avalanches or stone-fall are not uncommon in this short 60m couloir!).
routes.ascent: C.K. Ward and A.E. Talbot 1913.

routes.name: White Glacer Variation
routes.description: By late summer the above route may be cut by an icecliff for the width of the White Glacier. In this case a good route follows a scree/snow slope adjacent the ridge linking White Col and Kahutea Col. A cross over point onto the White Glacier neve is generally found about 200m up the ridge. In recent years (February) the White Glacier has been cut by a huge bergschrund for its entire width some 150m below Kahutea Col; rock bypasses are very risky to say the least.

routes.name: Kahutea Ridge
routes.description: The Kahutea ridge can be followed from White Col however be prepared for some very loose, exposed climbs, especially on the final two buttresses.

routes.name: From Upper Wlberforce River
routes.description: From the upper Wilberforce River via Denas Creek, by traversing upstream to a point directly below the summit rocks. A large scree leads up to a long steep couloir which meets the North Ridge not far from the summit. This route is fraught with dangers, avalanche, rock fall, and really rotten rock to name but a few. It is a seasonal route with a very narrow window of safe conditions (typically August to December, daily conditional). Descent is generally made over Kahutea Col, down the Kahutea Glacier (sticking true left), then sidling left diagonally down to gain the slabs and grassed slopes into Weka Stream.

routes.name: From Kahutea Glacier
routes.description: Follow the bouldery Weka Stream, to a basin at its head with bluffs on the eastern side. From here continue north along the base of bluffs, beyond the two side creeks draining the foot of the Kahutea Glacier, to a narrow scree slope hidden in the bluffs that trends up and right. Climb the scree and continue traversing up and right, crossing a rock rib above the northern-most of the two creeks that drain the Kahutea Glacier, and make a short descent into this creek down a slab with small ledges. This creek channels serac-fall debris from the snout of the glacier above and should be crossed quickly. Continue climbing up and right, and cross the top of the next side creek draining the glacier ; from here the glacier itself is a short climb. The true left of the glacier generally provides good travel to Kahutea Col ; from here traverse to the North Ridge and scramble up snow and loose rock on the north and east aspects to the summit.
routes.ascent: Neville Barker, Charles Gordon Buchanan, December 1934

routes.name: North and West Ridges
routes.description:
From a break in the scrub about 1 km east of Reischek Hut, climb a long scree slope to reach
either the North or West Ridge. The North Ridge provides a straightforward route to the summit
; the West Ridge is a steeper scramble.
routes.ascent: George Roberts, Charlie Douglas, 1880

routes.name: South Ridge
routes.description: Zig-zag through bluffs on scree ledges to reach the South Ridge and follow this to the summit.

routes.name: West Face
routes.description: Climb steep scree to reach a steeply left-rising scree ledge leading directly to the summit.

routes.name: South Ridge
routes.description:
Climb rotten rock ridges and small ledges, utilising a gully on the eastern side to reach the
summit.
routes.ascent: David Turnbull, Colin Burrows, March 1967

routes.name: Main Divide Ridges
routes.description: Once on the Main Divide, travel is straightforward.
routes.ascent: Roger Chester, Alan Willis, John Pascoe, December 1930

routes.name: From Chancellor
routes.description: From Chancellor descend a rock couloir leading straight down on the Joe River side to a snow saddle from where easy snow slopes lead to the summit. An alternative is to cross under Chancellor from Frobisher and ascend from the south.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aoraki/malt.name: Mt Nathan
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/aoraki/malt.description: Mt Nathan is believed to be unclimbed directly from the Murchison valley.

routes.name: North East Ridge
routes.description: Rather loose, exposed climbing.
routes.ascent: Mike Andrews, Donald Cargo, February 1973 (descended)

routes.name: Beetham Buttress
routes.description: Ascend the buttress right of the central gully on Barkley Face on mediocre quality rock.
routes.ascent: Harry Clark, Craig Nottle, December 1982

routes.name: South West Ridge
routes.description: Gained either by the Barkley Glacier and a couloir to the low point in the ridge between Mts Nathan and Chudleigh, or via the North West Ridge of Mt Chudleigh to the head of the Barkley Glacier, and then up the couloir. From here follow the ridge up loose rock to the summit. Probably the easiest descent route.
routes.ascent: Samuel Turner, February 1918

routes.name: East Face Routes
routes.description:
From the Ball Glacier gain the prominent shelf that runs below Nazomi and verges the Caroline Face by climbing 650m up a rib that starts from the Ball-Caroline glaciers junction. A number of routes exist from the shelf onto the crest of the Mt Aoraki/Cook Range:
Bruce Gillies, Roland Rodda, Dec 1942.
routes.ascent: i) to the base of the South Ridge of Nazomi.

https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/main-divide.name: Mt Neave
https://climbnz.org.nz/nz/si/main-divide.description:
Mt Neave is named after the original occupant of Mt Algidus Station (then called Neave’s Station),
who crossed Whitcombe Pass with Julius von Haast and Andreas Reischek in 1879.

routes.name: South Ridge
routes.description:
Head for the small permanent ice gully south-west of Mt Neave. Continue to the col and then
up very loose rock.
The first ascentionists followed Snag Creek, climbing out on the true left, then climbed the South Ridge and descended the West Ridge. However, it needs to be noted that maps at this
time all placed Snag Creek downstream of Neave Creek, while the metric series place Snag
Creek upstream. Their Snag Creek was probably today’s Neave Creek.
routes.ascent: Stan Davis, R I Kean, A F Thompson, O M Prebble, December 1934

routes.name: West Ridge
routes.description:
From the Whitcombe Valley, reasonable tussock access to the gravel basins under the Main
Divide exists around Cap Creek and Molar Stream. From the permanent ice at the head of
Neave Creek, pick a line through bluffs (crux) to reach the West Ridge between 2000 and
2100 metres. Other routes onto the ridge from lower down should also work and may be easier.
routes.ascent: R I Keen, A F Thompson, O M Prebble and S E Davis (descended), 26 December 1934

routes.name: North West Face
routes.description:
The original party bashed up through bush from Cave Camp and, forsaking the ridge, headed
